paper_name: Computational and Robustness Reproducibility of "UN Peacekeeping and Democratization in Conflict-Affected Countries"
description: This dataset contains country-year observations compiled from V-Dem, PEMA, World Bank, and UNHCR sources. It includes measures of democracy, democracy assistance, foreign aid, socioeconomic indicators, and country identifiers, with key variables lagged to reflect temporal relationships. Data variables: v2x_polarchy: Democracy index, from 0 (least), 1 (most democratic); ipema_any_demo_assist_dum_2l: Dummy indicator for any democracy assistance, lagged by 2 years; ipema_any_demo_assdiv_2l: Measures exogenous variation in democracy assistance, lagged by 2 years; iany_demo_all_max_dum_2l: Dummy indicator for maximum democracy assistance, lagged 2 years; iany_demo_all_maxdiv_2l: Measures exogenous variation in democracy assistance (max), lagged 2 years; iwdi_pop_3l: Population, lagged by 3 years; iwdi_oda_3l: Official development assistance (any foreign aid), lagged by 3 years; iwdi_gdppc_3l: GDP per capita, lagged by 3 years; iunhcr_ref_idp_3l: Number of refugees/internally displaced persons, lagged by 3 years; iwdi_literacy_3l: Literacy rate, lagged by 3 years; iwdi_fuel_3l: Access to fuel, lagged by 3 years; country: Country identifier (used for fixed effects via dummies)
natural_language_query: What is the effect of receiving the highest level of democracy assistance (vs. less or none) on democracy outcomes?
control_variables: iwdi_pop_3l, iwdi_oda_3l, iwdi_gdppc_3l, iunhcr_ref_idp_3l, iwdi_literacy_3l, iwdi_fuel_3l, country

paper_name: Incumbents Beware: The Impact of Offshoring on Elections
description: The dataset tracks municipalities in Spain across multiple election cycles to study the effect of local offshoring events on incumbent vote shares. Offshoring events were identified using corporate balance sheet databases, prior academic compilations, media reports, and public restructuring monitors. Each event was verified through at least two independent sources to ensure accuracy. For every confirmed event, the exact plant location and the number of jobs lost were recorded. These events were then matched with municipality-level election results to capture changes in incumbent party vote shares across elections. Additional contextual variables, such as population, unemployment, and economic growth, were obtained from official regional statistical agencies. Data variables: codi: Municipality code; year: Election year; spp: Incumbent party vote share (%); postp: Post-treatment period indicator; treatment_postp: Treatment _ Post period indicator; intensity_postp: Number of jobs lost due to offshoring; pop_thou: Population in thousands; urate: Local unemployment rate (%); yrrate: Local economic growth rate (%)
natural_language_query: Does experiencing an offshoring event cause a reduction in the incumbent government party's (PP) vote share in Catalan municipalities between the 2000 and 2004 elections?
control_variables: pop_thou, urate, yrrate

paper_name: Does mislabeling COVID-19 elicit the perception of threat and reduce blame?
description: This dataset comes from an online survey experiment conducted in the United States on Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) in March 2020, during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic. A total of 1,200 adult participants were included after excluding incomplete responses and failed manipulation checks. Respondents were randomly assigned to one of two groups: a control group where the virus was labeled COVID-19 and a treatment group where it was labeled the "Chinese Virus". The goal of the experiment was to test whether these labels influenced attitudes toward Chinese immigrants and shifted blame toward or away from the federal government. To capture sensitive views, the design combined a list experiment with direct survey questions. Dataset Variables: duration: the time subjects spent in survey; cblame_1: blame in COVID19 group; tblame_1: blame in "Chinese Virus" group; mc: answer of the manipulation check question; lc_c: list item count in 3-item COVID19 group; direct_c: answer of the direct question in the 3-item COVID19 group; lt_c: list item count in 4-item COVID19 group; lc_t: list item count in 3-item "Chinese Virus" group; direct_t: answer of the direct question in the 3-item "Chinese Virus" group; lt_t: list item count in 4-item "Chinese Virus" group; sex: 1=male; 0=female; age: subjects' age; race: subjects' race; income: subjects' income; worry: how worried subjects are about COVID-19 exposure; twitter: frequency of using Twitter/Facebook; party: party affiliation; lean: party lean; ideology: political ideology; state: subjects' location state; ch: 1="Chinese virus" group, 0=COVID19 group; covid: item number in COVID19 group (1=4-item; 0=3-item); virus: item number in "Chinese Virus" group (1=4-item; 0=3-item); list: item subgroup (1=4-item group; 0=3-item group); blame: blame; direct: answer of direct question; ict.c: item count in COVID19 group; ict.t: item count in "Chinese Virus" group; ict: item count; Y.c: social desirability measure in COVID19 group; Y.t: social desirability measure in "Chinese Virus" group; ido: numeric ideology measure; ido1: simplified measure of ideology; inc: numeric income measure; wor: numeric measure of worry; social: numeric measure of social media use; ID: subject ID; item: 3-item or 4-item; ch1: a=COVID19; b="Chinese Virus"; male: 1=male; 0=female; female: 1=female; 0=male; young: 1=age<=29; midage: 1=29<age<=49; old: 1=age>49; white: 1=white; 0=not white; blk: 1=black; 0=not black; his: 1=hispanic; 0=not hispanic; asian: 1=asian; 0=not asian; other: 1=other; 0=not other; hwor: 1=worried or very worried; 0=not too worried or not worried at all; lwor: 0=worried or very worried; 1=not too worried or not worried at all; hsocial: 1="social">=2; 0="social"<2; lsocial: 1="social"<2; 0="social">=2; Dem: 1=Democrat; 0=other; Rep: 1=Republican; 0=other; Ind: 1=Independent; 0=other; lib: 1=Liberal; 0=other; con: 1=Conservative; 0=other; mod: 1=Moderate; 0=other; low: 1=Less than $25,000; 0=other; med: 1="inc">=2 and <5; 0=other; high: 1="inc">=5; 0=other; mcr: 1=answer correct in manipulation check question; 0=answer wrong; group: covid3=COVID19 3-item group; covid4=COVID19 4-item group; virus3="Chinese Virus" 3-item group; virus4="Chinese Virus" 4-item group
natural_language_query: Does labeling COVID-19 as the 'Chinese Virus' causally affect the level of blame the public assigns to the federal government?

paper_name: Undermining U.S. reputation: Chinese vaccines and aid and the alternative provision of public goods during COVID-19
description: The data comes from an online panel survey conducted across 6 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, and Peru. The survey was conducted in two waves, before Chinese COVID-19 vaccines were available and after vaccination campaigns were being carried out extensively. In the first round, the survey gathered socio-demographic information and participants' views on the six countries. Meanwhile, the second wave contained vaccine-corrected questions, such as whether respondents had received the Chinese Covid-19 vaccine. Both surveys asked the participants' attitudes towards China and the USA. Data variables: wave: survey year (2020, 2021); duration: time spent by respondents in the survey; country: numeric country code; device: survey device used; sex: 0=female, 1=male; age: respondents' age; agerecode: age group code; vaccine: vaccination status; south_korea_score: favorability score assigned to South Korea; china_score: favorability score assigned to China; usa_score: favorability score assigned to the U.S.; japan_score: favorability score assigned to Japan; ideology: political ideology; education: highest education level; region_ar: Argentina subregion code; region_br: Brazil subregion code; region_co: Colombia subregion code; region_cl: Chile subregion code; region_mx: Mexico subregion code; region_pe: Peru subregion code; delta_china: change in favorability score for China; delta_usa: change in favorability score for the U.S.; income: respondents' income; region_code: numeric region identifier; country_name: name of the country; respondent_code: unique respondent identifier; news_experiment: treatment in survey experiment; both_waves: indicator if respondent answered both waves; excluded: indicator for excluded observations
natural_language_query: Does receiving a Chinese COVID-19 vaccine cause an increase in an individual's favorability toward China?

paper_name: China's Foreign Aid Political Drivers: Lessons from a Novel Dataset of Mask Diplomacy in Latin America during the COVID-19 Pandemic
description: This dataset contains information on 537 donations across 33 Latin American and Caribbean countries between 11 February and 20 June 2020. It details China's and Taiwan's mask diplomacy, including donors, recipients, donated items, and the political determinants of aid. The data highlight the influence of strategic partnerships, the One China Policy, and regime type in allocation decisions. Data variables: cow_code: country code; donor code: Donor code (1 = central government, 2 = provincial government, 3 = municipal government, 4 = university, 5 = enterprise, 6 = individual, 7 = foundation, 8 = other, 100 = Taiwan); amount_usd: Total value of donations (in millions); country: Name of the recipient country; iso_code: iso_code of the country; str_partnership: Partnership status with China (0 = No partnership, 1 = Partnership, 2 = Strategic Partnership, 3 = Comprehensive Strategic Partnership); taiwan: dummy variable that is 1 if the country has diplomatic relations with Taiwan; gdp_per_capita_log: the logarithm of gdp per capita; total_deaths_log: total deaths due to COVID-19; chinese_exports: total Chinese exports; chinese_exports_log: logarithm of the total Chinese exports to the country; democracy: Discrete variable for democracy status (0 = Autocracy; 1 = Anocracy; 2 = Weak democracy; 3 = Full democracy); amount_usd_log: logarithm of total donations; customs: total customs; customs_log: logarithm of total customs; agree_us: Measure of affinity with the United States; agree_cn: Measure of affinity with China; total_china: Total donations from China (in millions); total_china_ln: Logarithm of total donations from China
natural_language_query: Does having a strategic partnership with China increase the total Chinese foreign aid a country receives during COVID-19?
control_variables: democracy, taiwan, agree_us, chinese_exports_log, total_deaths_log, gdp_per_capita_log
remark: need to pre-process the data i.e. select only a portion of the data, where donor_code == 1

paper_name: Regression Discontinuity Designs Using Covariates
description: In 1965, the U.S. government launched the Head Start program to provide financial assistance to poor families. One of its primary goals was to reduce child mortality by expanding access to essential health services. To determine eligibility for Head Start funds, county-level poverty rates were calculated using data from the 1960 census. Counties with a poverty rate greater than 59.1984 were deemed eligible to apply for grants. Data variables: povrate60: Poverty rate constructed using data from the 1960 census; mort_age59_related_postHS: Mortality rate based on data after the rollout of the Head Start program; census1960_pop: Population based on the 1960 census; census1960_pctsch1417: Percentage of 14-17 year olds enrolled in school; census1960_pctsch534: Percentage of 5-34 year olds with formal education in schools; census1960_pctsch25plus: Percentage of people older than 25 with formal education in schools; census1960_pop1417: Number of individuals aged 14-17; census1960_pop534: Number of individuals aged 5-34; census1960_pop25plus: Number of individuals older than 25; census1960_pcturban: Percentage of individuals living in urban areas of the county; census1960_pctblack: Percentage of individuals who are Black
natural_language_query: Did the Head Start program help reduce the infant mortality rates?

paper_name: The influence of waiting times and sociopolitical variables on public trust in healthcare: A cross-sectional study of the NHS in England
description: This dataset contains individual-level survey responses from adults in England merged with local NHS performance measures on emergency and cancer referral waits covering July 2022 to July 2023. Each row corresponds to a respondent observation with institutional trust ratings, demographics, constituency-level context, and area-level waiting-time indicators linked via postcode outcodes to NHS Integrated Care Boards (ICBs) and ICB sub-units. Variable descriptions: id: Anonymous respondent identifier that uniquely indexes each survey record within the merged file; trustGov: Self-reported trust in "the Government in Westminster" on a 1-7 scale where 1 = Not at all and 7 = Completely; trustPM: Self-reported trust in the Prime Minister on the same 1-7 scale; trustParl: Self-reported trust in the UK Parliament on the 1-7 scale; trustMP: Self-reported trust in the respondent's local Member of Parliament on the 1-7 scale; trustNHS: Self-reported trust in the National Health Service on the 1-7 scale; trustPolice: Self-reported trust in the police on the 1-7 scale; trustCourts: Self-reported trust in the courts on the 1-7 scale; trustTradNews: Self-reported trust in news from traditional media on the 1-7 scale; trustSocNews: Self-reported trust in news shared on social media on the 1-7 scale; income: Personal annual income category with 14 brackets (under 5,000; 5,000-9,999; ...; 100,000+); emergencyDelay: Proportion of patients waiting more than 4 hours from decision to admit to admission across all A&E types in the respondent's ICB; cancerDelay: Proportion of GP-to-specialist cancer referrals breaching the two-week wait standard in the respondent's ICB sub-unit over July 2022-June 2023; ethnicity: Indicator for membership in an ethnic minority group, derived from survey responses/profile variables; london: Indicator for residence in the London region as defined in the nine-region classification used in the survey; conVote19: Indicator for whether the respondent reported voting Conservative in the 2019 UK General Election; women: Indicator for respondent's sex coded as female based on survey demographics; higherEd: Indicator for completion of higher education as reported in the survey; region: Categorical variable for the nine regions of England used to locate respondents; conShare: Conservative Party vote share (%) in the respondent's parliamentary constituency at the 2019 General Election; unemploymentRate: Constituency-level unemployment rate (%) matched to each respondent's parliamentary constituency; age: Respondent age in years (real-valued), spanning 18-98 across waves; W8: Respondent-level survey weight provided by the survey vendor for national representativeness across pooled monthly waves
natural_language_query: How does the local proportion of GP-to-specialist cancer referrals that breach the two-week wait standard affect individuals' reported trust in the NHS?
control_variables: income, emergencyDelay, ethnicity, conVote19, women, higherEd, region, conShare, unemploymentRate, age

paper_name: Europeanisation beyond the EU: Tobacco Advertisement Restrictions in Swiss Cantons
description: Swiss canton-year panel covering 1998-2010, tracking when each canton introduced a tobacco advertising restriction. Each row is a canton-year observed up to the year of adoption, with measures of EU-related public support, opinion on tobacco ads, neighboring adoptions, language composition, population, and party shares in government. Variables: year: Calendar year 1998-2010 for each canton-year record; canton: Canton identifier for the 26 Swiss cantons included in the panel; introad: Indicator equal to 1 in the year a canton's tobacco advertising restriction entered into force and 0 otherwise; euvote: Share voting in favor in popular votes on Switzerland-EU relations; puop: Public opinion proxy on tobacco advertising restrictions based on the 1992 national referendum result on banning tobacco and alcohol advertising; neighbourban: Count of neighboring jurisdictions with bans, including contiguous cantons and adjacent EU countries that had restricted tobacco advertising by that year; spatlag_n: Domestic spatial-lag variable built from the cantonal adjacency matrix; timegdk_98: Years a canton's health minister served on the board of the Conference of Cantonal Directors of Public Health (CDP/GDK) by that year; t1: Time trend measuring elapsed years since the start of the observation window; t1_2: Square of t1 divided by 10; t1_3: Cube of t1 divided by 100; tab: Indicator for tobacco economic presence, equal to 1 if the canton hosts a multinational tobacco plant and/or has tobacco cultivation; regcul: Index of regulatory density in other civil-life domains (e.g., schooling, church taxes, alcohol); gerpop: Share of residents who are German-speaking in the canton population; pop2: Overall canton population size; leftregperc: Share of cabinet seats held by left parties (Social Democrats and Greens) in the cantonal government; svpregperc: Share of cabinet seats held by the Swiss People's Party (SVP) in the cantonal government; cvpregperc: Share of cabinet seats held by the Christian Democrats (CVP) in the cantonal government; fdpregperc: Share of cabinet seats held by the Liberals (FDP) in the cantonal government
natural_language_query: How does support for European integration affect the probability that a canton adopts a tobacco advertisement restriction this year?
control_variables: tab, timegdk_98, spatlag_n, puop, regcul, svpregperc, cvpregperc, fdpregperc, gerpop, pop2, t1, t1_2, t1_3

paper_name: Does 'right to work' imperil the right to health? The effect of labour unions on workplace fatalities
description: This dataset consists of U.S. state-year panel covering 50 states from 1992-2016, combining annual counts of occupational fatalities, employed population, unionization rates, sectoral employment composition, and statutory right-to-work status; each row is a state-year observation with a derived fatality rate per 100,000 workers and its natural logarithm. The fatalities series comes from the Bureau of Labor Statistics' Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries, employment from BLS state employment data, unionization from the Union Membership and Coverage Database, and sectoral composition from BLS industry employment, yielding 1,250 total observations. Variables: state: State identifier (name or postal abbreviation) for each observation; year: Calendar year of the observation, ranging from 1992 to 2016; policy: Annual index of state policy liberalism capturing a state's overall regulatory orientation (higher values indicate more liberal policy environments); fatalities: Number of occupational fatalities in the state during the year from CFOI (count of deaths); employment: Employed population used to scale fatality counts to rates (number of workers or full-time equivalent workers); rate: Occupational fatality rate per 100,000 workers, computed as fatalities divided by employment and multiplied by 100,000; union: Unionization rate (share of workers who are union members or covered by a union contract) expressed in percentage points; trtraut: Number of workers employed in trade, transportation, and utilities in the state-year (industry employment count); pctttu: Share of workers employed in trade, transportation, and utilities (percent of total employment); mlc: Number of workers employed in mining, logging, and construction in the state-year (industry employment count); pctmlc: Share of workers employed in mining, logging, and construction (percent of total employment); manuf: Number of workers employed in manufacturing in the state-year (industry employment count); pctmanufacturing: Share of workers employed in manufacturing (percent of total employment); ST: State code used for grouping and identification in the dataset (numeric or categorical state code aligned with state); RTW: Indicator for whether a right-to-work law is in effect in that state-year (1 = RTW in force, 0 = otherwise); lr: Natural logarithm of the fatality rate variable to stabilize scale and interpret changes in proportional terms
natural_language_query: How does the percentage of unionised workers in a state effect the state's occupational fatality rate per 100,000 workers?
control_variables: policy, pctttu, pctmlc, pctmanufacturing

paper_name: The impact of intergenerational support on multidimensional poverty in old age (2023)
description: This study examines multidimensional poverty among senior citizens in China using data from the 2018 Chinese Longitudinal Healthy Longevity Survey (CLHLS). The dataset contains individual-level observations with variables measuring demographic characteristics, household composition, and social support factors. Variables: economicsupport: The logarithm of the amount the children give to the parent; emotionalsupport: Indicator specifying whether one receives emotional support through conversations with children (1 = yes, 0 = no); caresupport: Indicator specifying whether one is comfortable expressing their thoughts to children; gender: Respondent's gender (1 = male, 0 = female); age: Respondent's age in years; squareofage: Age squared; maritalstatus: Marital status (1 = with spouse, 0 = no spouse); householdregistration: Household registration (1 = urban, 0 = rural); totalnumberofchildren: Total number of children in the household; numberofboys: Number of male children in the household; proportionofboys: Proportion of boys among all children; totalhouseholdincome: Total household income (log of annual income last year); numberofpeoplelivingtogether: Number of people living in the household; region: Geographic region of the respondent (1 = eastern, 0 = not eastern); socialsecurity: Whether the respondent has social security (1 = yes, 0 = no); emotionalsupport: Whether the respondent receives emotional support (1 = yes, 0 = no); multidimensionalpoverty: Multidimensional poverty status (1 = yes, 0 = no); spiritualpoverty: Indicator denoting whether one feels lonely or not (1 = yes, 0 = no); rightspoverty: Indicator denoting whether one has final say in their business or not (1 = yes, 0 = no); economicpoverty: Indicator denoting whether the source of living is sufficient or not (1 = yes, 0 = no); healthpoverty: Indicator denoting whether one is healthy or not (1 = yes, 0 = no)
natural_language_query: How does receiving economic support affect spiritual poverty?
control_variables: caresupport, emotionalsupport, socialsecurity, gender, age, squareofage, maritalstatus, householdregistration, totalnumberofchildren, numberofboys, proportionofboys, totalhouseholdincome, numberofpeoplelivingtogether, region

paper_name: The impact of intergenerational support on multidimensional poverty in old age (2023)
description: This study examines multidimensional poverty among senior citizens in China using data from the 2018 Chinese Longitudinal Healthy Longevity Survey (CLHLS). The dataset contains individual-level observations with variables measuring demographic characteristics, household composition, and social support factors. Variables: economicsupport: The logarithm of the amount the children give to the parent; emotionalsupport: Indicator specifying whether one receives emotional support through conversations with children (1 = yes, 0 = no); caresupport: Indicator specifying whether one is comfortable expressing their thoughts to children; gender: Respondent's gender (1 = male, 0 = female); age: Respondent's age in years; squareofage: Age squared; maritalstatus: Marital status (1 = with spouse, 0 = no spouse); householdregistration: Household registration (1 = urban, 0 = rural); totalnumberofchildren: Total number of children in the household; numberofboys: Number of male children in the household; proportionofboys: Proportion of boys among all children; totalhouseholdincome: Total household income (log of annual income last year); numberofpeoplelivingtogether: Number of people living in the household; region: Geographic region of the respondent (1 = eastern, 0 = not eastern); socialsecurity: Whether the respondent has social security (1 = yes, 0 = no); emotionalsupport: Whether the respondent receives emotional support (1 = yes, 0 = no); multidimensionalpoverty: Multidimensional poverty status (1 = yes, 0 = no); spiritualpoverty: Indicator denoting whether one feels lonely or not (1 = yes, 0 = no); rightspoverty: Indicator denoting whether one has final say in their business or not (1 = yes, 0 = no); economicpoverty: Indicator denoting whether the source of living is sufficient or not (1 = yes, 0 = no); healthpoverty: Indicator denoting whether one is healthy or not (1 = yes, 0 = no)
natural_language_query: What is the effect of receiving emotional support on multidimensional poverty?
control_variables: socialsecurity, gender, age, squareofage, maritalstatus, householdregistration, totalnumberofchildren, numberofboys, proportionofboys, totalhouseholdincome, numberofpeoplelivingtogether, region

paper_name: The impact of intergenerational support on multidimensional poverty in old age (2023)
description: This study examines multidimensional poverty among senior citizens in China using data from the 2018 Chinese Longitudinal Healthy Longevity Survey (CLHLS). The dataset contains individual-level observations with variables measuring demographic characteristics, household composition, and social support factors. Variables: economicsupport: The logarithm of the amount the children give to the parent; emotionalsupport: Indicator specifying whether one receives emotional support through conversations with children (1 = yes, 0 = no); caresupport: Indicator specifying whether one is comfortable expressing their thoughts to children; gender: Respondent's gender (1 = male, 0 = female); age: Respondent's age in years; squareofage: Age squared; maritalstatus: Marital status (1 = with spouse, 0 = no spouse); householdregistration: Household registration (1 = urban, 0 = rural); totalnumberofchildren: Total number of children in the household; numberofboys: Number of male children in the household; proportionofboys: Proportion of boys among all children; totalhouseholdincome: Total household income (log of annual income last year); numberofpeoplelivingtogether: Number of people living in the household; region: Geographic region of the respondent (1 = eastern, 0 = not eastern); socialsecurity: Whether the respondent has social security (1 = yes, 0 = no); emotionalsupport: Whether the respondent receives emotional support (1 = yes, 0 = no); multidimensionalpoverty: Multidimensional poverty status (1 = yes, 0 = no); spiritualpoverty: Indicator denoting whether one feels lonely or not (1 = yes, 0 = no); rightspoverty: Indicator denoting whether one has final say in their business or not (1 = yes, 0 = no); economicpoverty: Indicator denoting whether the source of living is sufficient or not (1 = yes, 0 = no); healthpoverty: Indicator denoting whether one is healthy or not (1 = yes, 0 = no)
natural_language_query: How does receiving care support influence rights poverty?
control_variables: emotionalsupport, socialsecurity, gender, age, squareofage, maritalstatus, householdregistration, totalnumberofchildren, numberofboys, proportionofboys, totalhouseholdincome, numberofpeoplelivingtogether, region

paper_name: Internet-accessed sexually transmitted infection (e-STI) testing and results service: A randomised, single-blind, controlled trial
description: The data comes from a randomized control trial conducted to assess the impact of Internet-accessed sexually transmitted infection testing (e-STI testing) through the sh24 platform. Sexually active individuals between the ages of 16 and 30 were recruited. The participants were then randomly sent text messages inviting them to participate in the testing. The treatment group was asked to order the test online while the control group was asked to visit a walk-in clinic and take the test. The main outcome of interest was the self-reported diagnosis of STIs, supported by medical reports. Variables include: anon_id: Participant id; group: Allocation group ('Control' denotes control group and 'SH_24' denotes treatment group); imd_decile: Index of Multiple Deprivation decile rankings on scale of 1-10; 1 represents the most deprived and 10 represents the least deprived; partners: Number of sexual partners in past 12 months at baseline; gender: Gender (Male or Female); msm: Men who have sex with men ('msm'=Yes; 'other'=No; 99=Not Known); ethnicgrp: Ethnic group; age: Age in completed years at baseline; anytest_sr: Binary variable indicating whether the participant self-reported the completion of the STI test or not (1=tested, 0=not tested); anydiag_sr: Binary variable indicating whether the participant self-reported the diagnosis of STI test or not (1=diagnosed, 0=not diagnosed); anytreat_sr: Binary variable indicating whether the participant self-reported receiving STI treatment or not (1=treated, 0=not treated); anytest: Objectively verified binary indicator of STI testing completion (1 = tested, 0 = not tested); anydiag: Objectively verified binary indicator of STI diagnosis (1 = diagnosed, 0 = not diagnosed); anytreat: Objectively verified binary indicator of STI treatment (1 = treated, 0 = not treated); time_test: Time from randomization to test in days; time_treat: Time from randomization to treatment in days; sh24_launch: Binary variable indicating whether the randomization occurred before or after SH:24 was made publicly available (1 = yes, 0 = no)
natural_language_query: What is the effect of the e-STI testing service on the probability of getting tested for an STI by 6 weeks?
control_variables: age, male, msm, black, partners
remark: data available in the paper itself

paper_name: Estimating Incumbency Effects Using Regression Discontinuity Design
description: The dataset is a panel of electoral constituencies across multiple countries and years, designed to study incumbency effects. Each row corresponds to a party's performance in a given constituency at a given election. Dataset Variables: year: The year of the election; country: The country where the election took place (e.g., Canada, Japan, UK, USA, Romania, etc.); office: Name of the office being contested (e.g., House of Commons, Mayor); cst_n: Constituency identifier (e.g., "abbotsford", "abitibi"); l_vmargin: Lagged vote margin: the party's vote margin in the previous election (Values more than 0 indicate the party won (positive) and values less than 0 indicate the party lost (negative)); vmargin: Current vote margin: the party's vote margin in the current election; vs: Vote share of the party in the current election (between 0 and 1); win: Outcome of the current election: 1 means the party won the seat, 0 means the party lost; l_win: Lagged win indicator: 1 means the party won the previous election in this constituency, 0 means the party lost; inc: Incumbency indicator for the party's candidate in the current election: 1 means candidate is the incumbent, 0 means not incumbent, -1 appears to mark cases where incumbency is undefined or missing; office_num: Encoded office type, combining country and office (e.g., Canada, House); rd_s: Indicator variable that equals 1 if the observation is part of a subset of elections defined by narrow vote margins, and 0 otherwise
natural_language_query: In the UK, in very close elections, does just barely winning make it more likely that the party's candidate will stand again as the incumbent in the next election?

paper_name: Instrumental Variables Estimates of the Effect of Subsidized Training on the Quantiles of Trainee Earnings
description: This dataset was constructed to measure how subsidized Job Training Partnership Act (JTPA) programs affect not just average earnings but different points (quantiles) of the trainee earnings distribution. Data collection process: Data are drawn from the National JTPA Study - a large encouragement design randomized controlled trial under the JTPA. Eligible individuals were randomly assigned to be offered training services (treatment group) or excluded for 18 months (control group), with roughly 60% of those offered actually receiving training. Baseline demographic and economic covariates were collected before randomization, and earnings plus participation data were tracked for 30 months post-assignment via administrative records and follow-up interviews. Dataset variables: V1: Unique identifier for individuals; income: Individual's income (continuous, ranges from 0 to ~155,760); JTPA training offer: Whether the person was offered JTPA training (binary: 1 = yes, 0 = no); JTPA training participation: Whether the person actually participated in JTPA training (binary); male: Gender (1 = male, 0 = female); hsorged: Completed high school or earned a GED (1 = yes, 0 = no); black: Race indicator (1 = Black, 0 = otherwise); hispanic: Ethnicity indicator (1 = Hispanic, 0 = otherwise); married: Marital status (1 = married, 0 = unmarried); wkless13: Employment status: whether worked less than 13 weeks in the year before program entry (1 = yes, 0 = no); afdc: Receipt of Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC welfare program) (1 = yes, 0 = no); age2225: Age group indicator (22-25 years old); age2629: Age group indicator (26-29 years old); age3035: Age group indicator (30-35 years old); age3644: Age group indicator (36-44 years old); age4554: Age group indicator (45-54 years old); class_tr: Participation in classroom training (1 = yes, 0 = no); ojt_jsa: Participation in on-the-job training (OJT) or job search assistance (JSA); f2sms: Indicator for assignment to "Follow-up survey sample" or another experimental grouping
natural_language_query: What is the effect of receiving subsidized training on 30-month income of men?
control_variables: hsorged, black, hispanic, married, wkless13, class_tr, ojt_jsa, age2225, age2629, age3035, age3644, age4554
remark: needs minor preprocessing to select men only data

paper_name: Instrumental Variables Estimates of the Effect of Subsidized Training on the Quantiles of Trainee Earnings
description: This dataset was constructed to measure how subsidized Job Training Partnership Act (JTPA) programs affect not just average earnings but different points (quantiles) of the trainee earnings distribution. Data collection process: Data are drawn from the National JTPA Study - a large encouragement design randomized controlled trial under the JTPA. Eligible individuals were randomly assigned to be offered training services (treatment group) or excluded for 18 months (control group), with roughly 60% of those offered actually receiving training. Baseline demographic and economic covariates were collected before randomization, and earnings plus participation data were tracked for 30 months post-assignment via administrative records and follow-up interviews. Dataset variables: V1: Unique identifier for individuals; income: Individual's income (continuous, ranges from 0 to ~155,760); JTPA training offer: Whether the person was offered JTPA training (binary: 1 = yes, 0 = no); JTPA training participation: Whether the person actually participated in JTPA training (binary); male: Gender (1 = male, 0 = female); hsorged: Completed high school or earned a GED (1 = yes, 0 = no); black: Race indicator (1 = Black, 0 = otherwise); hispanic: Ethnicity indicator (1 = Hispanic, 0 = otherwise); married: Marital status (1 = married, 0 = unmarried); wkless13: Employment status: whether worked less than 13 weeks in the year before program entry (1 = yes, 0 = no); afdc: Receipt of Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC welfare program) (1 = yes, 0 = no); age2225: Age group indicator (22-25 years old); age2629: Age group indicator (26-29 years old); age3035: Age group indicator (30-35 years old); age3644: Age group indicator (36-44 years old); age4554: Age group indicator (45-54 years old); class_tr: Participation in classroom training (1 = yes, 0 = no); ojt_jsa: Participation in on-the-job training (OJT) or job search assistance (JSA); f2sms: Indicator for assignment to "Follow-up survey sample" or another experimental grouping
natural_language_query: What is the effect of receiving subsidized training on 30-month income of women?
control_variables: hsorged, black, hispanic, married, wkless13, class_tr, ojt_jsa, age2225, age2629, age3035, age3644, age4554, afdc
remark: needs minor preprocessing to select women only data

paper_name: Field Experiments Testing the Impact of Radio Advertisements on Electoral Competition
description: The dataset consists of 49 observations from mayoral elections in U.S. cities, with 33 observations from 2005 and 16 from 2006. The data is gathered through a randomized field experiment. Within matched pairs of municipalities, one city was randomly assigned to the treatment group and the other to the control group. The treatment involved a 60-second, non-partisan get-out-the-vote radio advertisement. The control group received no such intervention. The unit of observation is the city. Inclusion was limited to cities with populations over 30,000 where an incumbent mayor ran for reelection against an opponent. The study's outcome measure is the change in the incumbent mayor's vote share compared to the previous election. Variables: State: State; City: City; Contested_2006: Mayoral election contested; To_Prev: Turnout in prior mayoral election; Partisan: Partisan ballot; Inc_Voteshare_Prev: Incumbent vote percentage in prior mayoral election; Inc_Running_2006: Incumbent running in mayoral election; Grp_Buy: Gross Ratings Points purchased (measure of advertising intensity); Statewide_2005: Statewide election; Strata90: Low Cost-per-point stratum; Strata70: Moderate Cost-per-point stratum; Votesharechange: Change in incumbent vote percentage since prior mayoral election; Votesharediff: Margin of victory; Year_Exp: Experiment year
natural_language_query: What was the effect of the radio advertising campaign on the change in the incumbent mayor's vote share in the 2006 elections?
control_variables: Strata70, Strata90, Partisan, To_Prev, Statewide_2005

paper_name: Demand for in-app purchases in mobile appsA difference-in-difference approach
description: The dataset consists of user-level information, such as total number of purchases and total videos watched, associated with five "freemium" mobile app games in six European markets for the years 2017-2022. The games are available on both iOS and Android platforms. However, only Apple changed its pricing tiers in between, as a result of which the prices of the games changed on the iOS platform. Data Variables: game: Anonymized codenames of the games (W1-W5); country: Two-letter country code (France, Germany, Great Britain, Italy, Netherlands, and Sweden); platform: Gaming platform (Android or ios); dt: Date; norm_users: Number of users normalized; norm_purch_users: Normalized number of users who purchase premium; norm_videos: Number of rewarded videos watched; purchsmooth: Number of purchases smoothed; year: Year recorded; month: Month recorded (1-12); apple: Dummy variable for ios platform (1 = platform is ios, 0 = otherwise); google: Dummy variable for android platform (1 = platform is android, 0 = otherwise); post: Indicator of the time period after price change (1 = post price change, 0 = pre price change); window: Not applicable; userssmooth: Number of users smoothed; postxapple: Interaction between post and apple; forpan: Concatenation of game codename, country, and platform; cgn: Concatenation of country and game codename
natural_language_query: Does the logarithm of the number of users who purchase premium change after the price of premium is altered?
control_variables: game, country, year, month
remark: need to first create the logarithm of the users; log(norm_purch_users)

paper_name: Comparing public support for nuclear and wind energy in Washington State
description: This data comes from a survey administered in the state of Washington. Adults 18 years and older were first asked to read about the challenges to addressing the rising demands of energy while meeting decarbonization goals. To begin with, the participants were asked to answer attention-check questions. These were multiple-choice questions. Then, the participants were asked to indicate their degree of support for nuclear and wind energy sources. Additionally, participants were asked questions about factors that explain their preference for wind or nuclear energy sources. Dataset Variables: Outcome: The difference in support level between nuclear and wind (nuclear support % minus wind support %); Nuclear: Level of nuclear support (0-100%); Wind: Level of wind support (0-100%); Dist_nuclear: Distance in miles from respondent's county to the Richland nuclear power plant; Dist_wind: Distance in miles from respondent's county to the closest wind facility; Region: Geographic region (Eastern or Western Washington); Urban_rural: Binary variable indicating whether respondents live in urban (county population >10,000) or rural areas; 1 = urban, 0 = rural; Health: Importance attached to health effects of electricity generation and waste disposal (scale 1-4, where 1="not important at all", 4="very important"); Job: Importance attached to local jobs and economic benefits (scale 1-4, where 1="not important at all", 4="very important"); Landscape: Importance attached to disruption of the rural landscape (scale 1-4, where 1="not important at all", 4="very important"); Supply: Importance attached to reliability of electricity supply (scale 1-4, where 1="not important at all", 4="very important"); Trust_reg: Trust in the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission (1 = no trust at all, 4 = trust very strongly); Trust_health: Trust in Washington State Department of Health (1 = no trust at all, 4 = trust very strongly); Trust_plant: Trust in nuclear plant operators (1 = no trust at all, 4 = trust very strongly); Env: Environmental attitude - priority given to environmental protection (1) vs. economic growth (2); Gender: Respondent gender; Age: Age categories by birth year (1946-1964, 1965-1996, After 1996); Income: Income categories ($40,000-$69,999, $70,000-$104,999, $105,000-$159,999, $160,000+); Education: Education level (High school incomplete, High school, College no degree, 4 yrs college, Graduate school); Race: Racial/ethnic identification; Religion: Religious affiliation; PID: Party identification (Democrat, Independent, Republican); AC1: Attention check question 1 answer; AC2: Attention check question 2 answer; AC3: Attention check question 3 answer; AC: Overall attention check performance
natural_language_query: Does the distance to nuclear facilities influence the difference in a person's support for nuclear or wind energy?
control_variables: Dist_wind, Health, Job, Landscape, Supply, Gender, Age, Income, Education, Race, Religion, PID

paper_name: Does rising income inequality affect mortality rates in advanced economies?
description: This dataset aims to study the effect of income inequality on mortality rates for men and women in a subset of OECD countries from 1950 to 2000 using adult mortality rates at age sixty-five as the measure of mortality. Likewise, for measuring income inequality, the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient was used. The coefficient is directly obtained from the World Top Income Database. More specifically, the measure was derived from individual taxation and income data as well as national account statistics. The Pareto-Lorenz coefficient ranges from 1.5 to 3. Values in the range of 1.5 to 1.8 are considered low inequality, while values above 2.5 are considered high inequality. Data variables: year: Year observation was taken; cc: Country code; qxall: Averaged rate between qxfemale and qxmale; qxfemale: Five-year mortality rate for females at age sixty-five (the probability of dying within 5 years for 65-year-old women); invertedplc: Inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient (measure of income inequality at the top end of distribution, ranging from ~1.5-3); exfemale: Life expectancy for females at age 65; qxmale: Five-year mortality rate for males at age sixty-five (the probability of dying within 5 years for 65-year-old men); exmale: Life expectancy for males (at age 65); country: Country name; rgdpe: Real GDP obtained from Penn World Table; values adjusted for purchasing power parity; pop: Population (in millions); hc: Health capital index - a measure capturing educational attainment that serves as a proxy for human capital stock; rpcgdp: Real per capita GDP - GDP per person adjusted for purchasing power parity
natural_language_query: Does a greater inequality in income lead to a higher average mortality rate among males and females?
control_variables: pop, hc, rgdpe

paper_name: Inference with 'Difference in Differences' with a Small Number of Policy Changes (Merit dataset)
description: Individual-level U.S. Current Population Survey (CPS) microdata pooled across states and years (late 1980s-2000). Each row is a person-year observation with demographics plus state and year identifiers suitable for fixed-effects analysis. The sample spans all 50 states plus DC. Variables: coll: Whether the person is enrolled in college (1 = yes, 0 = no); merit: Statewide merit-aid program in effect in that state-year (1 = yes, 0 = no); male: Respondent's gender (1 = male, 0 = female); black: Race indicator (1 = Black/African American, 0 = otherwise); asian: Race indicator (1 = Asian, 0 = otherwise); year: CPS survey year (e.g., 1989-2000); state: Numeric CPS state code identifying the respondent's state (includes DC); chst: "Changer state" flag (1 = state that adopts a merit program during the sample window, 0 = otherwise)
natural_language_query: What is the effect of the Merit scholarship on college attendance?
control_variables: male, black, asian

paper_name: Inference with 'Difference in Differences' with a Small Number of Policy Changes
description: Individual-level U.S. Current Population Survey (CPS) data pooled across years and states (late 1980s-2000). Each row is a person-year observation with demographics plus state and year identifiers for fixed-effects analysis. Georgia's HOPE (Helping Outstanding Pupils Educationally) scholarship program provided two years of full tuition for high school graduates with a B average and family income below $66,000. Variables: collegeAttendance: Whether the person is currently enrolled in college (1 = yes, 0 = no); hopeScholarship: Policy indicator for Georgia's HOPE program being in effect for that observation (1 = HOPE in effect for the person's state/year, 0 = otherwise); male: Respondent's gender (1 = male, 0 = female); black: Race indicator (1 = Black/African American, 0 = otherwise); asian: Race indicator (1 = Asian, 0 = otherwise); year: CPS survey year (e.g., 1989-2000); state: Numeric state code from the CPS identifying the respondent's state (includes DC)
natural_language_query: What is the effect of the HOPE scholarship on college attendance?
control_variables: male, black, asian

paper_name: Dismantling the 'Jungle': migrant relocation and extreme voting in France
description: This dataset combines municipal-level information from across France to study the political effects of migrant relocation after the dismantling of the Calais "Jungle" between 2015 and 2016. Data on temporary migrant reception centers, called Centres d'Accueil et d'Orientation (CAOs), were collected through a combination of systematic searches in local newspapers using Factiva and a publicly released dataset by CIMADE in October 2016. The media search recorded CAO locations and migrant counts reported in articles, while the CIMADE dataset listed 210 centers and their capacities. By merging these two sources, the final dataset includes 349 CAOs, closely matching the official government count of 365 centers. CAO capacity was measured either using the maximum number of migrants reported in media articles or the number of beds provided in the CIMADE dataset. Variables: period: A discrete variable representing the time period (1 = pre-2012, 2 = 2012, 3 = 2017); log_fn: The natural logarithm of the vote share for the far-right party, Front National (FN); log_melenchon: The natural logarithm of the vote share for Jean-Luc Melenchon, a far-left candidate; log_turnout: The natural logarithm of the voter turnout rate; evol2_fn_2012_2017: The change in the log of the FN vote share between the 2012 and 2017 presidential elections; evol2_melench_2012_2017: The change in the log of the Melenchon vote share between 2012 and 2017; evol2_turnout: The change in the log of the voter turnout rate between 2012 and 2017; right_: A binary variable indicating if the mayor of the municipality is right-wing; CAO: A dummy variable indicating if a municipality hosted a Centre d'Accueil et d'Orientation (CAO), a temporary migrant reception center; CAO_period_1: A binary variable indicating the presence of a CAO during the first period (pre-2012, period = 1); CAO_period_2: A binary variable indicating the presence of a CAO during the second period (2012, period = 2); CAO_period_3: A binary variable indicating the presence of a CAO during the third period (2017, period = 3); period_1: Time period before 2012 (1 = time period before 2012, 0 = otherwise); period_2: Indicator for the year 2012 (1 = year 2012, 0 = otherwise); period_3: Indicator for the year 2017 (1 = year 2017, 0 = otherwise); ring5_CAO_period_3: A spatial spillover variable indicating the presence of a CAO within a 5 km radius of the municipality; ring10_CAO_period_3: A spatial spillover variable indicating the presence of a CAO within a 10 km radius of the municipality; ring15_CAO_period_3: A spatial spillover variable indicating the presence of a CAO within a 15 km radius of the municipality; tot_places_CAO_per1000: The total number of places in CAO centers per 1,000 inhabitants; migshare_: The share of foreign-born individuals (migrants) in the total population; num_group_vv: The number of group accommodation buildings used as an instrumental variable; volontaires_migrants: The number or share of volunteer migrants; evol_CADA_2012_2016: The change in the number of places in Centres d'Accueil pour Demandeurs d'Asile (CADA) between 2012 and 2016; log_tot_pop_: The natural logarithm of the total population; share_0014_: The share of the population aged 0 to 14; share_60p_: The share of the population aged 60 and over; log_median_inc_: The natural logarithm of the median disposable income; share_chom1564_: The share of the population aged 15-64 that is unemployed; female_: The proportion or count of females in the population; age_: The average age of the population; CSP_agri_: The share of the population in the agricultural socio-professional category; CSP_ind_: The share of the population in the industrial socio-professional category; CSP_sal_: The share of the population in the sales socio-professional category; CSP_lib_: The share of the population in the liberal professions socio-professional category; CSP_ens_: The share of the population in the education socio-professional category; CSP_func_: The share of the population in the public servants socio-professional category; CSP_div_: The share of the population in the diverse socio-professional category; CSP_retr_: The share of the population in the retired socio-professional category; coastal: A binary variable indicating if a municipality is located on the coast; log_hotel_rooms: The natural logarithm of the number of hotel rooms; log_min_dist_center: The natural logarithm of the minimum distance to a major city center; codeinsee: The INSEE code, a unique identifier for each French municipality; numdep: The unique identifier for a French administrative department
natural_language_query: What is the effect of having a migrant reception center (CAO) on the vote share of the Front National (FN) for the year 2012 - 2017?
remark: needs preprocessing. We use data for the periods 2 and 3 only.

paper_name: Blame Shifting in Presidential Systems: Ministerial Terminations' Corrective Effect on Approval
description: This dataset comes from a comprehensive archival review of Latin American governments spanning multiple decades. It combines digitized historical records, semi-supervised machine learning to classify calls for ministerial resignation, and survey-based presidential approval estimates to study the corrective effects of ministerial dismissals on presidential popularity. The dataset includes quarterly observations and political, economic, and institutional covariates to analyze blame-shifting dynamics in presidential systems. Variables: country: Name of the country corresponding to the quarterly observation; honeymoon_1q: Dummy indicating the first quarter of a newly inaugurated presidential term (1 = yes; 0 = no); honeymoon_2q: Dummy indicating the second quarter of a presidential term's honeymoon period (1 = yes; 0 = no); honeymoon_3q: Dummy indicating the third quarter of a presidential term's honeymoon period (1 = yes; 0 = no); preelection_1q: Dummy indicating one quarter before a scheduled presidential election (1 = yes; 0 = no); preelection_2q: Dummy indicating two quarters before a scheduled presidential election (1 = yes; 0 = no); dismissal_tainted: Number of ministers dismissed after receiving calls for resignation; age: Average age of all cabinet members at the end of the quarter; nonpartisan: Proportion of ministers in the cabinet who are not affiliated with any political party; inflation: Quarterly inflation rate (World Bank); gdp: Gross domestic product metric (World Bank); allhouse: Binary indicator whether president's party holds absolute majority in legislative houses (1 = yes; 0 = no); govfrac: Index measuring probability two government deputies belong to different parties (0-1); reelect_last_year: Binary indicating if president could run for re-election in last year of term (1 = yes; 0 = no); coalition: Binary indicating presence of multi-party governing coalition (1 = yes; 0 = no); lagged_approval: Prior quarter's smoothed presidential approval estimate; approval: Smoothed quarterly presidential approval measure (current quarter); lagged_rc: Aggregate number of calls for resignation received by any cabinet member in previous quarter; lagged_dism_tainted: Number of tainted ministers dismissed in previous quarter; lagged_age: Average age of cabinet members in previous quarter; lagged_nonpartisan: Proportion of nonpartisan ministers in previous quarter's cabinet; visibility: Binary indicating whether calls for resignation concerned high-visibility topics (1 = yes; 0 = no); qtr: Unique identifier for each quarterly observation (YYYYqN)
natural_language_query: How does dismissing tainted ministers affect presidential approval?
control_variables: lagged_rc, lagged_rc_sq, visibility, allhouse, coalition, reelect_last_year, govfrac, gdp, inflation, honeymoon_2q, honeymoon_3q, preelection_1q, preelection_2q
remark: needs preprocessing to create lagged_age^2

paper_name: Evaluating the Minority Candidate Penalty with a Regression Discontinuity Approach
description: This dataset contains information on U.S. state legislative primary and general elections, focusing on competitive races where the top two primary candidates differed by race or ethnicity, enabling analysis of electoral outcomes when parties nominate candidates of different racial backgrounds. Variables: year.x: Election year of the contest; general2p: Party's two-party vote share in the general election for that district-year (NA if the general was uncontested); general2palt: Alternative outcome that codes uncontested generals as 1 for the party's nominee; otherwise same as general2p; minorityprimarymargin: Primary election win margin of the minority candidate calculated as minority candidate vote share minus white candidate vote share; incumbentrunning: Indicator that the seat's incumbent entered the party primary (1 = incumbent ran; 0 = open seat); incumbentwins: Indicator that the incumbent won the party primary (1 = nominee is the seat's incumbent); womanwins: Indicator that the party's primary winner/nominee is a woman (1 = yes, 0 = no); party: Party of the contest (e.g., "Democratic", "Republican"); Dem_2pyShare: District Democratic two-party presidential vote share (2016) - baseline partisan lean; Total.x: District population; uniquedist_noyear: District identifier without year (e.g., "MA 0 TWELFTH SUFFOLK"; includes a chamber flag); uniquedist: Unique district-year identifier (e.g., "2018 MA 0 Twelfth Suffolk"); pctWhite, pctBlack, pctLatino, pctAsian: Racial/ethnic composition of the district; share of residents who are White, Black, Latino, Asian, respectively; RDDBlack: Indicator that the primary matchup was Black vs. White; RDDLatino: Indicator that the primary matchup was Latino vs. White; RDDAsian: Indicator that the primary matchup was Asian vs. White; uncontestedgen: Indicator that the general election was uncontested for that party (1 = no major-party opponent); Upper.x: Chamber indicator (1 = upper chamber/senate; 0 = lower chamber/house); mmd2keep: Flag for multi-member districts (NA = single-member (kept), 1 = multi-member districts)
natural_language_query: How does the effect of nominating a minority candidate affect the general election vote share?

paper_name: Causal measures using generalized difference-in-difference approach with nonlinear models
description:
This data analyzes the demographic impacts of the Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak. The virus was first detected in 2015; the state of Pernambuco (PE) was strongly aﬀected by the epidemic, while the southernmost state of Rio Grande do Sul (RS) had no reported case. The data consists of a time series of annual births and birth rates extracted from administrative databases on 682 municipalities (185 in PE and 497 in RS) during the period from 2008 to 2016. 

Dataset variables:
 
- StudyYear: The year of data collection
- Code: Municipality code
- Births: Overall number of births in a year 
- BirthSchool: Births among mothers >= 8 years of schooling
- Rate: Birth rate 
- trt: Whether a municipality experienced the Zika epidemic or not (1 = state of Pernambuco, 0 = Rio Grande do Sul )
- year: Indicator for study year (1 = After 2015, the year when virus was detected; 0 = Before 2015)
- interaction: Interaction between trt and year
- Pop: Total population count for each municipality
natural_language_query: Does the presence of a Zika epidemic in a municipality lead to lower birth rates?

paper_name: Social Capital, Racial Context, and Incarcerations in the American States
description:
This study examines the differential effects of social capital on policy equity in state outcomes between 1986 and 2009. Specifically, it explores the relationship between social capital and incarceration rates in the American states paying particular attention to racial disparities in incarceration rates. State-level incarceration rates from 1986 to 2009 were obtained from the Bureau of Justice Statistics National Prisoners Statistics study. social capital is measured using an index created by Hawes, Rocha, and Meier (2013) using factor analysis of 22 items that capture the behavioral components of social capital. This index primarily relies on state-level data from a market research firm (MediaMark, Inc.) that conducts large annual surveys that include items related to organizational membership, volunteerism, and civic engagement.

Data Variables:
statename: State Name; year: Year; fips: FIPS State Code; fipsyear: FIPS Code + Year; VCRate_Total: Total Violent Crimes per 100,000 population; PCRate_Total: Total Property Crimes per 100,000 population; divorcerate: Divorce per 1,000 population; women_leg: Percent Females in State Legislature; SC8609_ma: Social Capital Index; pop_pctblk: Percent Black Population; felonspc: Voting-Ineligible Felons per 100,000; bwpovratio: Poverty Inequality (Black/White Ratio); bwcolratio: Education Inequality (Black/White Ratio); pov_rtfull: Poverty Rate; unemp: Unemployment Rate; govideo: Government Ideology; totdempct: Proportion of Democrats in Entire Legislature; racialdiversity: Racial Diversity (Blau Index); gsppc_k: GSP per Capita (in 2007 $1000); eduattain_ma: Percent with College Degree; SC_RD: Social Capital X Racial Diversity; jprison_totalrt: Total Inmates per 100,000 population; prison_whtrt: White Inmates per 100,000 population; prison_blkrt: Black Inmates per 100,000 population; prison_BWratio: Black/White Incarceration Ratio; ln_prison_BWratio: Logged Black/White Incarceration Ratio; ln_pctblk: Logged Percent Black Population; ln_SC_PBLK: Social Capital X ln(% Black); threestrikes: Three Strikes Law (Yes/No); GTClear: Trial Court Clearance Rate; darrest2: Drug Arrests / Population; blk_leg: Percent African Americans in State Legislature
natural_language_query: Does an increase in social capital increase the ratio of Black/White prisoners?
control_variables: VCRate_Total, PCRate_Total, divorcerate, women_leg, pop_pctblk, felonspc, bwpovratio, bwcolratio, unemp, racialdiversity, govideo, threestrikes, blk_leg, totdempct, eduattain_ma, ln_SC_PBLK, SC_RD

paper_name: Impact of the Out-of-School Nutrition and Physical Activity (OSNAP) Group Randomized Controlled Trial on Children's Food, Beverage, and Calorie Consumption among Snacks Served
description: This dataset contains data describing dietary consumption of snacks served by afterschool programs in the OSNAP group randomized trial. This longitudinal dataset that covers baseline and follow periods of the trial was used to investigate the effectiveness of the OSNAP intervention on a number of children's dietary intake outcomes (e.g., changes in ounces of juice consumed, servings of fruits and vegetables, calories consumed). Dietary consumption data was collected on two days at baseline and two days at follow up for each child. Variables: siteid: Site indicator; age: Age of the child in years; male: Male or female identifier (0 = Female, 1 = Male); race: Race of the child (Black, Hispanic/Latino, Asian, Multiracial, Cape Verdean, Black Hispanic, -1 = missing) with White as reference; childid: Unique child identifier; foodservice: Satellite Foodservice provided (on-site, satellite, independent); osnap: Enrollment in OSNAP; pair: Matched pairs; obsdate: Observation date; s_juiceoz_consumed: Ounces of 100% juice consumed per snack; s_fv_consumed: Servings of fruits & vegetables consumed per snack; s_pho_consumed: Servings of foods with trans fats consumed per snack; s_wg_consumed: Servings of whole grains consumed per snack; s_kcal_consumed: Calories(kcals) consumed per snack; s_bevkcal_consumed: Beverage calories(kcals) consumed per snack; sdayps: [description missing]; post: Collected post-hoc; firstday: day of data collection as a binary variable (0 not first day, 1 first day)
natural_language_query: Does enrollment in OSNAP lead to a reduction in the number of beverage calories consumed by a child?
control_variables: age, male, race, firstday, pair

paper_name: The Effect of Microinsurance on Economic Activities: Evidence from a Randomized Field Experiment
description: The dataset is the result of a randomized controlled trial conducted to study the effect of insurance on farming behavior. Each village consists of at least one AHW (Animal Husbandry Worker), who is involved in tasks such as animal immunization, providing technical assistance to farmers, etc. As part of the experiment, AHWs are assigned to different incentive schemes associated with the number of sow insurance purchases. In the control group villages, AHWs were offered a reward of 50 yuan to participate. In the low incentive group (LIG), the AHW is offered 20 Yuan to begin with, and an additional payment of 2 Yuan for each insured sow. Finally, in the high incentive group (HIG), the AHWs are offered a starting payment of 20 Yuan and an additional 4 Yuan for each insured sow. At the end of the experiment, data on total sows in each village were obtained. Variables: sow0: No. of Sows in Dec. 2006; sow1: No. of Sows in Sept. 2007; sow2: No. of Sows in Dec. 2007; pig: No. of Pigs in Dec. 2006; goat: No. of Goats in Dec 2006; pop_regist: Village Population; pop_migout: No. of Villagers as Migrant Workers; age_vil: Ave. Villager Age; edu_vil: Ave. Villager Education (Years); male_vil: Fraction Male in Village; land: Land per Household (Mu); house_val: House Value (RMB yuan); lhouse_val: Log House Value; surname_vil: No. of Surnames in the Village; no_xnh: No. of Villagers in New Medical Coop. Scheme; subsidy: No. of Households Receiving Gov. Subsidy; insuredpig: No. of Insured Sows; snow: No. of Sow Deaths in Snow Storm; sow3: No. of Sows in March 2008; sow4: No. of Sows in June 2008; group: Coding for different groups (1 = Control Group; 2 = Low incentive Group; 3 = High Incentive Group); groupd1: Control Group Dummy; groupd2: Low Incentive Group Dummy; groupd3: High Incentive Dummy; villageid: Village Id; villagename: Village Name (in Chinese); snow_insured: No. of Sow Deaths in Snow Storm Interact with No. of Insured Sows; towndummy1-26: 26 Town dummies; sow2008: No. of sows at the end of 2008; sow2009: No. of sows at the end of 2009; sow2010: No. of sows at the end of 2010; sow2011: No. of sows at the end of 2011; pig2008: No. of pigs at the end of 2008; pig2009: No. of pigs at the end of 2009; pig2010: No. of pigs at the end of 2010; pig2011: No. of pigs at the end of 2011; sheep2008: No. of sheep at the end of 2008; cow2008: No. of cows at the end of 2008; sow200810: Average sows 2008-2010; pig200810: Average pigs 2008-2010; lnhouse: Log House Value; insured_house: Insured Sows _ Log House Value; insured_edu: Insured Sows _ Avg. Villager Education; snow_house: Sow Deaths _ Log House Value; snow_edu: Sow Deaths _ Avg. Villager Education; insured_house_snow: insured_house _ snow; insured_edu_snow: insured_edu _ snow; house_groupd2: Log House Value _ Low Incentive Dummy; house_groupd3: Log House Value _ High Incentive Dummy; house_snow_gd2: snow_house _ Low Incentive Dummy; house_snow_gd3: snow_house _ High Incentive Dummy; edu_groupd2: Avg. Villager Education _ Low Incentive Dummy; edu_groupd3: Avg. Villager Education _ High Incentive Dummy; edu_snow_gd2: insured_edu _ snow _ Low Incentive Dummy; edu_snow_gd3: insured_edu _ snow _ High Incentive Dummy
natural_language_query: Did an increase in the number of insured sows lead to an increase in the number of sows owned in March 2008?

paper_name: Does Electing Women Reduce Corruption? A Regression Discontinuity Approach
description: The study aims to investigate whether there is a causal link between the share of women in office and malfeasance in Spain. In 2007, Spain's Organic Law 3/2007 on Effective Equality between Women and Men introduced mandatory gender quotas for electoral lists. The law established a 40% minimum quota requirement, mandating that political parties include at least 40% (and no more than 60%) of candidates of each sex on every electoral list. Variable description: muni_code: statistical code for each municipality; Welec: Number of women elected in 2007; MainParty: Most voted party 2007; AlcParty: Mayor's party; FemAlc: Woman mayor = 1; pop: Population; Wshare: Share of women in council; Wshare03: Share of women in council 2003-2007; FemAlc03: Woman mayor in 2003 = 1; Area_hec: Municipality area; opland07: Open land 2007; pop03: Population 2003; corr0711: Corruption cases 07-11; corr0307: Corruption cases 03-07; corr1115: Corruption cases 11-15; nuc711: Change in urban land 07-11; nuc37: Change in urban land 03-07; nvac7: Vacant land; PP03: PP mayor 2003; PSOE03: PSOE mayor 2003; ec: Economic activity index 2006; const: Construction sector index 2006; tur: Tourism sector index 2006; ind: Industry sector index 2006; com: Business index 2006; bancos: Number of banks
natural_language_query: What is the effect of the gender quota enacted in 2007 on corruption cases between the 2003 - 2007 and 2007 - 2011 terms?

paper_name: Do Term Limits Restrain State Fiscal Policy? Approaches for Causal Inference in Assessing the Effects of Legislative Institut
description:
This dataset contains state-level panel data examining fiscal policy outcomes across U.S. states during a period of significant variation in legislative term limits. The data spans multiple decades, capturing the adoption and subsequent repeal of term limits across states. The term limits movement began in 1990 with California, Colorado, and Oklahoma, followed by a major wave in 1992 when eight additional states adopted restrictions. By 2000, twenty-one states had implemented term limits on state legislators. However, several states later repealed these limits through court decisions or legislative action. Currently, fifteen states maintain active term limits while six have repealed previously enacted restrictions.

Variable description:
exp_real_pc: real per capita expenditure
tl_onset: whether a term limit was active in that year
population: population
popgrowth: relative population growth with respect to the previous year
populationdensity: population density
grants_real_pc: federal grants per capita
gsp_real_inc: real gross state product per capita
fedempciv_pc: federal employment per capita
fedempmil_pc: federal military employment per capita
govtempsandl_pc: state and local employment per capita
seats_house: number of seats in the house of representatives
seats_senate: number of seats in the senate
unemployment: unemployment rate
gopshare: share of votes for the republican party
demcontrol: whether the state is controlled by the democratic party
dividedgov: whether the state has a divided government
squire_score: squire score
initiatives: number of initiatives
tel: whether the state has implemented tax and expenditure limitations
debtlimit: whether the state has a debt limit
year: year
fips: state code (Federal Information Processing Standards code)
state: state name, may contain spelling errors"
natural_language_query: Does term limits have any effect on a states per capita expenditures?
control_variables: population, popgrowth, populationdensity, grants_real_pc, gsp_real_inc, fedempciv_pc, fedempmil_pc, govtempsandl_pc, seats_house, seats_senate, unemployment, gopshare, demcontrol, dividedgov, squire_score, initiatives, tel, debtlimit, fips

paper_name: Evaluating the Econometric Evaluations of Training Programs with Experimental Data
description: The dataset contains the results of a randomized control trial associated with a job training program. Participants in the treatment group were provided training to enhance their job skills, while participants in the control group did not receive any training. Data on the demographics and the incomes of the participants, both before and after the program, were collected. Similarly, data on earnings post-program completion were also collected. Data Variables: treat: treatment indicator (1 if treated, 0 if not treated); age: age; education: education; black: Black (1 if black, 0 otherwise); hispanic: Hispanic (1 if Hispanic, 0 otherwise); married: married (1 if married, 0 otherwise); nodegree: nodegree (1 if no degree, 0 otherwise); re75: RE75 (earnings in 1975); re78: RE78 (earnings in 1978); income_change: income change

paper_name: Do female politicians empower women to vote or run for office? A regression discontinuity approach
description: The dataset aims to study the influence of electing women officials on women's participation in subsequent elections. It uses data from US districts with close election races between men and women candidates. In the contests, candidates with more than 50% of the vote win. Variable description: Year: Election Year; State: US state abbreviation; Chamber: Whether the election is for the House (H) or the Senate (S); Name: Name of the candidate contesting the current election; Pty: Political party (R = republican, D = democrat, IP = independent) of the female candidate; Seat: Status of the contesting seat (I: incumbent, O = Open, etc.); GE_Win: Outcome of the election (Won or lost); womanwon: Binary variable indicating whether a woman won the election or not (1 = Won, 0 = Lost); femalecand_margin_of_victory: Margin of victory for the candidates (negative values if the candidate lost); fem_v_c_p_2: Margin of victory squared; fem_v_c_p_3: Margin of victory cubed; fem_v_c_p_4: Margin of victory raised to the fourth power; femaleonballotnextyear: Share of women on the next election, i.e., women's voter turnout; winXfem_v_c_p: Interaction between womanwon and femalecand_margin_of_victory; winXfem_v_c_p_2: Interaction between womanwon and fem_v_c_p_2; winXfem_v_c_p_3: Interaction between womanwon and fem_v_c_p_3; winXfem_v_c_p_4: Interaction between womanwon and fem_v_c_p_4; absolute_margin: absolute margin of victory of one candidate over the other in the last election, i.e., abs(femalecand_margin_of_victory); femaleonballotnextyear: Binary variable indicating if a female is on the ballot of the next year's elections (1 = yes, 0 = no); femaleturnout_thiscycle: Fraction of females that turned out to vote in the reference election; femaleturnout_nextcycle: Fraction of females that turned out to vote in the next election; female_percentageofelectorate_th: Fraction of females in the voter electorate for the reference election; female_percentageofelectorate_ne: Fraction of females in the voter electorate for the next election; overall_voterturnout_thiscycle: Overall voter turnout in the reference election cycle; overall_voterturnout_nextcycle: Overall voter turnout in the next election cycle

paper_name: Partisan Imbalance in Regression Discontinuity Studies Based on Electoral Thresholds
description: The dataset contains the results of state-level elections: House, Senate, and Governor. It includes data on the share of the Democrats in the election and the outcomes. An election is won by the party that secures voter share greater than 0.5. paper_name: The Causal Effect of Radical Right Success on Mainstream Parties' Policy Positions. A Regression Discontinuity Approach
description: The dataset aims to analyze the effect of radical right parties on the policy positions of the mainstream parties. It includes information on political parties belonging to various European countries, including their positions on cultural protectionism and environmental protectionism. Each country has minimum thresholds for voter shares that the political parties need to meet to get into the parliament. Thresholds vary by country, so in this dataset, we used voter shares centered around the threshold. Variable description: iso2c: iso2 character country code; edate: election date; party: CMP-code mainstream party; partyname: name of mainstream party; parfam: party family of mainstream party (CMP-coding); thrs: electoral threshold; thrs_l: electoral threshold (lagged); er.v.c: radical right party vote share (centered on electoral threshold); er.v.c_l: radical right party vote share (centered on electoral threshold, lagged); er.in: radical right parliamentary presence (binary indicator); er.in_l: radical right parliamentary presence (binary indicator, lagged); rile.logit: rile score (according to Lowe et al. 2011); per607: multiculturalism positive (CMP coding); per608: multiculturalism negative (CMP coding); multic.logit_fd: cultural protectionism score (Lowe version, first difference); per608_fd: per608 score (first difference); multic.ratio_fd: cultural protectionism score (Kim and Fording version, first difference); af.bipolar_fd: cultural protectionism score (Alonso and da Fonseca version, first difference); meguid.bipolar_fd: cultural protectionism score (Meguid 2008 version, first difference); env.logit_fd: environment protection score (Lowe version, first difference)

paper_name: The Causal Effect of Radical Right Success on Mainstream Parties' Policy Positions. A Regression Discontinuity Approach
description: The dataset aims to analyze the effect of radical right parties on the policy positions of the mainstream parties. It includes information on political parties belonging to various European countries, including their positions on cultural protectionism and environmental protectionism. Each country has minimum thresholds for voter shares that the political parties need to meet to get into the parliament. Thresholds vary by country, so in this dataset, we used voter shares centered around the threshold. Similarly, whether a party is rightist or leftist can be determined from the rile score. The classification varies from country to country. Parties with rile scores less than the mean rile scores of all the parties in the given country are classified as leftist. Variable description: iso2c: iso2 character country code; edate: election date; party: CMP-code mainstream party; partyname: name of mainstream party; parfam: party family of mainstream party (CMP-coding); thrs: electoral threshold; thrs_l: electoral threshold (lagged); er.v.c: radical right party vote share (centered on electoral threshold); er.v.c_l: radical right party vote share (centered on electoral threshold, lagged); er.in: radical right parliamentary presence (binary indicator); er.in_l: radical right parliamentary presence (binary indicator, lagged); rile.logit: rile score (according to Lowe et al. 2011); per607: multiculturalism positive (CMP coding); per608: multiculturalism negative (CMP coding); multic.logit_fd: cultural protectionism score (Lowe version, first difference); per608_fd: per608 score (first difference); multic.ratio_fd: cultural protectionism score (Kim and Fording version, first difference); af.bipolar_fd: cultural protectionism score (Alonso and da Fonseca version, first difference); meguid.bipolar_fd: cultural protectionism score (Meguid 2008 version, first difference); env.logit_fd: environment protection score (Lowe version, first difference)
