paper_name: Does earmarked funding affect the performance of international organisations?
description: The dataset compiles performance evaluations of 32 international organizations (IOs) from 2009 to 2021, encompassing 64 assessments conducted by the Multilateral Organization Performance Assessment Network (MOPAN). Organizations vary significantly in their funding composition, with some receiving predominantly core contributions that provide operational flexibility, while others rely heavily on earmarked resources that restrict fund usage to specific purposes, sectors, or geographic areas. Due to their specific nature, earmarked funding does not offer flexibility. Thus, there is a possibility that earmarked funding may limit organizational performance. The dataset tracks both short-term and long-term earmarked funding patterns alongside core funding levels. International organizations' performance is given by two metrics: 1) Process performance, the extent to which organizations have rules to plan and manage operations strategically, and 2) outcome performance, which measures the organization's success in achieving desired results. Variables: organization: international organization name; acronym: organization abbreviation; year: assessment year; mopan: The version of MOPAN methodology used in the assessment (one of 3.0, 3.1, or 3.0*, CA = older version); newmopan: Binary variable that is 1 if the new MOPAN assessment methodology was used; y1: process performance factor score; y2: outcome performance factor score; y1n: process performance factor score after removing 2 micro indicators; y2n: outcome performance factor score after removing 2 micro indicators; EMST: earmarked funding share in the year before MOPAN assessment (t-1 year); EMLT: earmarked funding share in the years t-2 and t-3 before MOPAN assessment, i.e., 2 and 3 years before; un: indicator for UN system organizations (1 = UN organization, 0 = non-UN organization); coreSTd: non-core funding amount; coreST: core funding amount; emST: earmarked funding amount; emST_MBI: earmarked funding amount computed by MOPAN; emshareLTd: Share of earmarked funding in the IO budget based on data from UN DESA Data; emshareLTb: Share of earmarked funding in the IO budget based on data from UN Data Cube; emshareLT: Share of earmarked funding share for long-term projects; nproj_lt: number of earmarked projects; ndon_lt: number of donors providing earmarked funding; states_num: number of member states; states_unga_sd: standard deviation of the preferences of the member states with respect to ideal point estimates; tenure: executive head tenure length; selectorate: Variable indicating how the executive is selected (1 = appointed by the chief of parent organization, 2 = selected by the board, 3 = chosen by the assembly of member states); founding: organization founding year; hq: headquarters location; field_presence: number of staff in the field; staff_count: total staff size; normio: indicator for norm-making IOs: FAO, ILO, UNESCO, UNHCR, UNIDO, WHO, GEF; lnsectors: logarithm of the number of sectors in which the organization receives donor funding; meanwSIM: weighted mean cosine similarity of sector-specific contribution profile, which is proportional to the total budget of the IOs
natural_language_query: How much does earmarked funding share in the preceding year affect the process performance of international organisations?
control_variables: newmopan

paper_name: Cabinets, Committees, and Careers: The Causal Effect of Committee Service
description: The dataset comes from French parliamentary records across multiple legislative sessions. It is structured by deputy-year, and includes variables for legislative behavior, career success, policy-making, tenure, and constituent characteristics. An interesting feature of the lower house was that the legislature was randomly assigned into 11 groups called bureaux, and each group chose members to serve on the budget committee. The deputies convened with their assigned group, and after hours of discussion, each bureau nominated three representatives to serve on the budget committee. Bureaux was a temporary committee, and the selection was done every year. This random selection of bureaux (or bureau) for budget selection was done from 1894 to 1910, after which it was disbanded. Variable description: id: ID number (Unique identifier for each deputy); year: Year (1894-1909); term: Term (1893, 1898, 1902, or 1906); leader: Deputy was any type of party leader (defined as a member of a parliamentary governing committee) (1 = yes, 0 = no); centrist_all: Deputy was a member of a Radical or Radical-Socialist party (1 = Radical socialist, 0 = radical party); inscrits: Number of electors in deputy's district (in 000s); permargin: Electoral margin of prior election, as a ratio of total votes cast; paris: Whether the deputy represents a Parisian district or suburb (1 = Parisian district, 0 = suburb); age: Age of deputy; bureau: Deputy's bureau number (assignment) for that year; budget: Deputy was on the budget committee (1 = yes, 0 = no); min: Deputy was a minister (1 = yes, 0 = no); termyear: Identifier for term + year; budgettermyears: Number of years a deputy has served on the budget committee, including the current year; budgetexptermyears: Budget experience in years; proprietaire: Deputy was a property owner (upper class) (1 = yes, 0 = no); lib_all: Deputy held a liberal profession (middle class) (1 = yes, 0 = no); civil: Deputy was a civil servant (1 = yes, 0 = no); reelect: Deputy was reelected the next term (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5firstminyear: Became a minister for the first time within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5firstleaderyear: Became a party leader within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); cummyears: Years of parliamentary experience; clburyear: Identifier for term year + bureau; budgetincumbent: Deputy was a budget incumbent (1 = yes, 0 = no); bureauotherbudgetincumbent: Number of budget incumbents in deputy's bureau (excluding deputy); reelectterm: Deputy was reelected the next term (1 = yes, 0 = no); reelecttwoterm: Deputy was reelected within the next two terms (1 = yes, 0 = no); senate: Deputy was a senator (1 = yes, 0 = no); rannext: Deputy ran for reelection in the subsequent term (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5senateyear: Became a senator within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5billdummy: Sponsored a bill within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5billfinancedummy: Sponsored a finance bill within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5billecondummy: Sponsored an econ bill within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5billwelfaredummy: Sponsored a welfare bill within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5billbudgetdummy: Sponsored a budget bill within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5billagendadummy: Sponsored an agenda bill within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5billinterpdummy: Sponsored an interpellation bill within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5cosponsordummy: Cosponsored a budget bill within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); F1to5cosponsordummy_anybm: Co-sponsored with current or previous budget committee member within 5 years (1 = yes, 0 = no); cummyears2: Years of parliamentary experience squared; age2: Age, squared; inscrits2: Electors, squared; permargin2: Electoral Margin of Prior Election, squared; deptcode: Department ID
natural_language_query: Does a deputy being on the budget committee increase the likelihood of sponsoring a budget bill?
control_variables: age, age2, inscrits, inscrits2, permargin, permargin2, cummyears, cummyears2, proprietaire, lib_all, civil, paris, budgetincumbent, year

paper_name: Improving Balance in Regression Discontinuity Design by Matching: Estimating the Effect of Academic Probation after the First Year of College
description: This dataset comprises comprehensive academic records from a large Canadian university system, consisting of one central campus and two smaller satellite campuses. The data tracks 12,530 first-year students who entered the university between the 1996-97 and 2003-04 academic years, with students aged 17-21 at entry. The dataset focuses on students whose academic performance places them near institutional academic standing thresholds, specifically those with first-year GPAs within a range of the university's academic evaluation criteria. Different campuses maintain distinct GPA cutoffs for academic standing assessments, resulting in variations in institutional policies across the university system. Students are placed on academic probation if their GPA falls below the cutoffs. The longitudinal structure captures academic performance across multiple terms and years, including semester and cumulative GPAs, total credits attempted and completed, registration patterns for fall and summer terms, and academic standing determinations. Outcome measures track graduation status at 4, 5, and 6-year intervals, along with probation and suspension incidents. Variable description: winter_ac_standing: winter academic standing status (OKAY or PROB (indicating probation)); GPA_year1: grade point average by academic year 1; GPA_year2: grade point average for academic year 2; CGPA_year1: cumulative grade point average for year 1; CGPA_year2: cumulative grade point average for year 2; totcredits_year1: total academic credits attempted in year 1; totcredits_year2: total academic credits attempted in year 2; winter_ac_stand_year1: winter academic standing status in year 1 (OKAY or PROB (indicating probation)); winter_ac_stand_year2: winter academic standing status in year 2 (OKAY or PROB (indicating probation)); goodstanding_year1: binary representation of winter_ac_stand_year1; Indicator for academic standing (1 = OKAY, 0 = PROB); goodstanding_year2: binary representation of winter_ac_stand_year2; Indicator for academic standing (1 = OKAY, 0 = PROB); fallreg_year1: fall term registration status in year 1 (1 = registered, 0 = not registered); fallreg_year2: fall term registration status in year 2 (1 = registered, 0 = not registered); summerreg_year1: summer term registration status in year 1; summerreg_year2: summer term registration status in year 2; sex: Sex of the student (MALE / FEMALE); female: 1 = FEMALE, 0 = otherwise; male: 1 = MALE, 0 = otherwise; mtongue: mother tongue language; age_at_entry: student age at university entry; bpl_north_america, bpl_asia, bpl_other: Binary variables to indicate birth place regions (1 = born in that region, 0 = not born in that region); canadian: Canadian citizenship status (1 = yes, 0 = no); firstyear: year the student first entered the university; yearstodegree: time taken to complete the degree; gradin4, gradin5, gradin6: Binary variables that indicate if the student graduated within the specified years; cumcredits1, cumcredits2: cumulative credits completed in years 1 and 2; prog_science/prog_socsci_bus/prog_socscihum: binary variable that indicates the academic program of the student: science, social science, humanities; english, french, other_lang: binary variable indicating whether the student's main language is English, French, or some other language; gpacutoff: GPA evaluation threshold; dist_from_cut: distance from academic threshold; probation_year1: probation status by year 1; probation_year2: probation status by year 2; suspended_year1: suspension status by year 1; suspended_year2: suspension status by year 2; loc_campus1, loc_campus2, loc_campus3: Binary indicators for campus location; hsgrade_pct: high school grade percentile; veryhighHS, highHS, lowHS: Binary indicators for high school performance; hsgrade_pct: overall percentage achieved in high school; left_school: binary variable representing whether the student left school (1) or not (0)
natural_language_query: Are students placed on academic probation after their first year likely to leave their studies at the university?

paper_name: Deep IV: A Flexible Approach for Counterfactual Prediction
description: This dataset contains simulated consumer behavior data examining relationships between pricing decisions and market demand across various emotional and temporal contexts. The data structure reflects a complex economic environment where pricing strategies may be influenced by factors that also affect consumer demand. Pricing information is represented through both continuous normalized measures and categorical indicators distinguishing between different price levels. The data captures market demand responses across various pricing scenarios, with additional variables tracking price positioning within broader market distributions. Variable description: obs_id: unique observation identifier; seed: randomization seed for simulation; treatment_price_normalized: standardized pricing measure; outcome_demand: consumer demand response; instrument_z: auxiliary variable for pricing analysis; temporal_time: time measurement; state_emotion_id: emotional state category identifier; takes values 0, 1, 2, ..., 6; covariate_emotion_0 to covariate_emotion_6: emotional state indicators across seven categories; unobserved_confounder_v: unmeasured factor affecting pricing and demand; price_percentile: pricing position within market distribution; treatment_high_price: indicator for high pricing condition; treatment_low_price: indicator for low pricing condition; instrument_strong: strength indicator for auxiliary pricing variable; time_category: categorical time period; counterfactual_demand_low_price: hypothetical demand under low pricing; counterfactual_demand_high_price: hypothetical demand under high pricing; individual_treatment_effect: person-specific response to pricing changes
natural_language_query: How does increase in product cost affect customer demand?

remark: This is a synthetic data with known effects.

paper_name: Do Politicians Racially Discriminate Against Constituents? A Field Experiment on State Legislators
description: This study utilizes randomized field experiments to examine the interactions between constituents and state legislators across the United States during October 2008. Legislators across multiple states were sent an email asking for help with the voter registration process for the primary election using black (DeShawn Jackson) or white alias names (Jake Mueller). The sender name, the legislature receiving the email, and the (hypothetical) party affiliation of the sender were randomly assigned. Not all letters included information on which political party's primary election the sender was interested in. Legislative offices were contacted through official email addresses posted on state government websites. The outcome of interest is whether the legislator responded by the November election date or not. Variable Descriptions: leg_party: Political party affiliation of the state legislator (R = Republican, D = Democrat); leg_republican: Binary indicator for legislators affiliated with the Republican Party; leg_black: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as Black or African American; leg_latino: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as Latino or Hispanic; leg_white: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as white; leg_notwhite: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as non-white; leg_notblackotherminority: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as minorities other than Black (including Latino, Asian American, Native American, and Arab American legislators); reply_atall: Binary indicator for whether the legislative office provided any form of response to the constituent inquiry; treat_deshawn: Binary indicator for communications associated with the name "DeShawn Jackson"; treat_jake: Binary indicator for communications associated with the name "Jake Mueller"; treat_group: Categorical variable indicating the specific combination of communication characteristics; treat_demprimary: Binary indicator for communications that mentioned interest in Democratic primary elections; treat_repprimary: Binary indicator for communications that mentioned interest in Republican primary elections; treat_noprimary: Binary indicator for communications that did not specify any particular primary election interest; treat_primary: Binary indicator for communications that included any reference to primary election participation (either Democratic or Republican)
natural_language_query: Do legislators respond more often to black alias names when no partisan signal is included in the email?
control_variables: leg_republican, leg_black, leg_latino, leg_white, leg_notwhite, leg_notblackotherminority

Not all letters included information on which political party's primary election the sender was interested in. Legislative offices were contacted through official email addresses posted on state government websites. The outcome of interest is whether the legislator responded by the November election date or not. Variable Descriptions: leg_party: Political party affiliation of the state legislator (R = Republican, D = Democrat); leg_republican: Binary indicator for legislators affiliated with the Republican Party; leg_black: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as Black or African American; leg_latino: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as Latino or Hispanic; leg_white: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as white; leg_notwhite: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as non-white; leg_notblackotherminority: Binary indicator for legislators who identify as minorities other than Black (including Latino, Asian American, Native American, and Arab American legislators); reply_atall: Binary indicator for whether the legislative office provided any form of response to the constituent inquiry; treat_deshawn: Binary indicator for communications associated with the name "DeShawn Jackson"; treat_jake: Binary indicator for communications associated with the name "Jake Mueller"; treat_group: Categorical variable indicating the specific combination of communication characteristics; treat_demprimary: Binary indicator for communications that mentioned interest in Democratic primary elections; treat_repprimary: Binary indicator for communications that mentioned interest in Republican primary elections; treat_noprimary: Binary indicator for communications that did not specify any particular primary election interest; treat_primary: Binary indicator for communications that included any reference to primary election participation (either Democratic or Republican)
natural_language_query: Do legislators respond differently to black alias names when the recipient signals interest in Republican primary?
control_variables: leg_republican, leg_black, leg_latino, leg_white, leg_notwhite, leg_notblackotherminority, treat_repprimary

description: This study examines community organizations and public safety patterns across major US cities during a period of significant social change from 1990 to 2013. Variable Descriptions: poprank: Population-based ranking of cities within the national urban hierarchy; agency: Law enforcement agency responsible for crime reporting in each jurisdiction; place_name: Official name of the municipal entity; place_id: Unique numerical identifier for each city; place_id_str: String version of the unique place identifier; state_ab: Two-letter state postal abbreviation; state_id: Numerical state identifier; state_name: Full state name; region: Census region classification code; region_str: Census region name designation; division: US Census Bureau division classification; year: Calendar year of observation (1990-2013); year_str: Year designation in string format; years_crime: Total number of years for which crime data is available for each city; first_crime: Earliest year of available crime data; last_crime: Most recent year of available crime data; y_1990 through y_2012: Binary indicators for each individual year in the dataset; year_region: Combined year and region identifier; year_region_num: Numerical encoding of year-region combinations; year_reg_1 through year_reg_120: Individual year-region interaction indicators; totpop: Total resident population count; pop2010: Population count as recorded in the 2010 Census; pop1990: Population count as recorded in the 1990 Census; pop2000: Population count as recorded in the 2000 Census; popweights: Statistical weights based on population size; area: Overall geographic area of the municipal boundary; popdens: Population density per square unit of area; logpop: Natural logarithm of the 1990 population; logpopdens: Natural logarithm of population density; largest50: Binary indicator for cities ranking among the 50 most populous in the US; largest100: Binary indicator for cities ranking among the 100 most populous in the US; viol: Absolute count of violent crimes reported annually; viol_r: Violent crime rate per 100,000 residents; murd: Absolute count of homicides reported annually; murd_r: Murder rate per 100,000 residents; rape: Absolute count of reported sexual assaults; rape_r: Sexual assault rate per 100,000 residents; robbery: Absolute count of reported robberies; robbery_r: Robbery rate per 100,000 residents; assault: Absolute count of reported aggravated assaults; assault_r: Aggravated assault rate per 100,000 residents; prop: Absolute count of property crimes reported annually; prop_r: Property crime rate per 100,000 residents; burglary: Absolute count of reported burglaries; burglary_r: Burglary rate per 100,000 residents; larceny: Absolute count of reported larceny-theft incidents; larceny_r: Larceny-theft rate per 100,000 residents; autotheft: Absolute count of reported motor vehicle thefts; autotheft_r: Motor vehicle theft rate per 100,000 residents; community_new: Count of newly established community-focused nonprofit organizations; community_cml: Cumulative count of active community-focused nonprofit organizations; crime_new: Count of newly established crime prevention organizations; crime_cml: Cumulative count of active crime prevention organizations; housing_new: Count of newly established housing-related organizations; housing_cml: Cumulative count of active housing-related organizations; jobs_new: Count of newly established workforce development organizations; jobs_cml: Cumulative count of active workforce development organizations; nhood_new: Count of newly established neighborhood development organizations; nhood_cml: Cumulative count of active neighborhood development organizations; reentry_new: Count of newly established prisoner reentry support organizations; reentry_cml: Cumulative count of active prisoner reentry support organizations; substance_new: Count of newly established substance abuse prevention organizations; substance_cml: Cumulative count of active substance abuse prevention organizations; youth_new: Count of newly established youth-related organizations; youth_cml: Cumulative count of active youth-related organizations; Various _r suffixed variables: Rate calculations expressing organizational counts per 100,000 residents (for example, substance_cml_r represents the cumulative count of substance-abuse prevention organizations per 100,000 residents); all_new_r: Rate of all newly established nonprofits per 100,000 residents; all_cml_r: Rate of all cumulative active nonprofits per 100,000 residents; white: Percentage of residents identifying as white (non-Hispanic); black: Percentage of residents identifying as Black or African American; asian: Percentage of residents identifying as Asian; hispanic: Percentage of residents identifying as Hispanic or Latino; other: Percentage of residents identifying with other racial/ethnic categories; fborn: Percentage of foreign-born residents; male1524: Percentage of male residents aged 15 to 24 years; female1524: Percentage of female residents aged 15 to 24 years; lesshs: Percentage of residents 25 years and older without a high school diploma; college: Percentage of residents 25 years and older with a bachelor's degree or higher; hsdropout: High school dropout rate; unemployed: Overall unemployment rate; unemployed_male: Male-specific unemployment rate; unemployed_female: Female-specific unemployment rate; notlabforce: Percentage of residents not participating in the labor force; notlabforce_male: Percentage of males not participating in the labor force; notlabforce_female: Percentage of females not participating in the labor force; manufacturing: Percentage of employed residents working in manufacturing industries; poverty: Percentage of residents living below the federal poverty line; vacancy: Housing vacancy rate; incarceration: Incarceration Rate; log_incarceration: Natural logarithm of incarceration rate; swornftime_r: Number of sworn police officers per capita; iv_cml: Cumulative number of new non-profits focusing on the arts, medical research, and environmental protectionism; iv_cml_r: Cumulative number of new non-profits focusing on the arts, medical research, and environmental protectionism per 100,000 residents; log_viol_r: Natural logarithm of violent crime rate; log_prop_r: Natural logarithm of property crime rate; log_murd_r: Natural logarithm of murder rate; Multiple lagged difference variables (log_viol_r_1ld through log_viol_r_5ld): Historical differences in log violent crime rates over 1-5 year periods; Multiple lagged growth variables (log_viol_r_1lg through log_viol_r_5lg): Historical growth patterns in log violent crime rates over 1-5 year periods; Similar lagged difference and growth variables for property crime (log_prop_r_Xld/lg) and murder rates (log_murd_r_Xld/lg)
natural_language_query: Does local nonprofit communities have a causal effect on the logarithm of violent crime rates?
control_variables: popdens, asian, black, hispanic, other, lesshs, college, fborn, male1524, poverty, unemployed, manufacturing

paper_name: The Minimum Legal Drinking Age and Crime
description: This dataset contains comprehensive arrest and criminal justice records from California covering individuals around their 21st birthday. The data captures detailed information on various types of criminal offenses, demographic characteristics, and temporal variables that enable analysis of crime patterns across different age groups. The dataset includes both raw count data and population-adjusted rates for multiple categories of criminal activity, spanning from serious felonies to minor infractions and regulatory violations. Variable Descriptions: days_to_21: Number of days until or since an individual's 21st birthday years_to_21: Years until or since turning 21 all: Total number of arrests across all offense categories felony: Count of felony-level arrests misdemeanor: Count of misdemeanor-level arrests fbi_offense_miss: FBI-classified misdemeanor offenses violent: Total violent crime arrests murder: Homicide arrests manslaughter: Manslaughter arrests rape: Sexual assault arrests robbery: Robbery arrests assault: Total assault arrests aggravated_assault: Aggravated assault arrests ot_assault: Other types of assault property: Total property crime arrests burglary: Burglary arrests larceny: Theft arrests mv_theft: Motor vehicle theft arrests stolen_prop_buy_rec_poss: Receiving stolen property arrests vandalism: Property damage arrests ill_drugs: Total drug-related arrests cocaine_opio_sale_manuf: Cocaine/opiate sales and manufacturing arrests mj_sale_manuf: Marijuana sales and manufacturing arrests dang_non_narc_sale_manuf: Other dangerous drug sales/manufacturing arrests cocaine_opio_posses: Cocaine/opiate possession arrests mj_posses: Marijuana possession arrests dang_non_narc_posses: Other dangerous drug possession arrests alcohol: Total alcohol-related arrests drunk_at_risk: Public intoxication arrests dui: Driving under the influence arrests liquor_laws: Liquor law violation arrests drunkeness_pc: Public drunkenness arrests disorderly_cond: Disorderly conduct arrests vagrancy: Vagrancy arrests arson: Arson arrests forgery_counterfit: Forgery and counterfeiting arrests fraud: Fraud arrests embezelment: Embezzlement arrests weapons: Weapons violations prostitution: Prostitution arrests sex_offenses: Sexual offense arrests bookmaking: Illegal gambling arrests all_other_gambling: Other gambling violations aga_family_child: Offenses against family and children curfew_loitering: Curfew and loitering violations runaways: Runaway arrests coded_on_offense: Arrests coded by primary offense county_ordinance: County ordinance violations outside_warrent: Out-of-jurisdiction warrant arrests traffic_violations: Traffic violation arrests hit_run_reckl_driv: Hit and run/reckless driving arrests parole_violation: Parole violation arrests dump_or_litter: Illegal dumping/littering violations trespass: Trespassing arrests violate_court_order: Court order violations failure_to_appear: Failure to appear in court cont_delinq_minor: Contributing to the delinquency of a minor not_classified: Unclassified arrests other_reported: Other reported offenses pop1, pop2, pop3: Population counts for different demographic groups pop_day1, pop_day2, pop_day3: Daily population estimates post: Binary indicator variable that is 1 if age >= 21, i.e., the individual is 21 linear, square, cubic: years_to_21 raised to the power of 1, 2, and 3 respectively linear_post, square_post, cubic_post: Interaction of linear, square, cubic with post birthday_19, birthday_20, birthday_21, birthday_22, birthday_23: Dummy variables for 19th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, and 23rd birthdays birthday_19_1, birthday_20_1, birthday_21_1, birthday_22_1, birthday_23_1: Dummy variables for a day after the 19th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, and 23rd birthdays All variables with _r suffix represent population-adjusted rates corresponding to their count variable counterparts. These include crime-specific rates such as violent_r, property_r, alcohol_r, dui_r, and all_r, among others. The rate variables normalize the raw counts by relevant population denominators.
natural_language_query: How does gaining legal access to alcohol at age 21 affect overall arrest rates?
control_variables: birthday_19, birthday_19_1, birthday_20, birthday_20_1, birthday_21, birthday_21_1, birthday_22, birthday_22_1, birthday_23, birthday_23_1, linear, square, linear_post, square_post

paper_name: The Minimum Legal Drinking Age and Crime
description: This dataset contains comprehensive arrest and criminal justice records from California covering individuals around their 21st birthday. The data captures detailed information on various types of criminal offenses, demographic characteristics, and temporal variables that enable analysis of crime patterns across different age groups. The dataset includes both raw count data and population-adjusted rates for multiple categories of criminal activity, spanning from serious felonies to minor infractions and regulatory violations. paper_name: Countering misinformation via WhatsApp: Preliminary evidence from the COVID-19 pandemic in Zimbabwe
description: The data aims to test whether trusted WhatsApp messages can counter COVID-19 misinformation in Zimbabwe. Partnering with Internews and Kubatana, the researchers crafted short weekly messages: Week 1 emphasized transmission and social distancing, Week 2 debunked fake cures. At the WhatsApp broadcast list level, timing was randomized: treatment groups received messages on Monday, control groups on Saturday. To measure effects, a survey was sent on Thursday. Knowledge was assessed through factual questions, and behavior through a list experiment, where respondents received either a short list (only non-sensitive activities) or a long list (the same activities plus a sensitive one: visiting others during lockdown). Broadcast lists were blocked in groups of four, with random assignment across timing (treatment vs. control) and list length (short vs. long). Data variables ResponseId: identifier for the responses from the individuals Behavior: number of activities the respondent participated in, coded from 0 to 5 Id: identifier for individuals participating List: binary variable, equals 1 if the WhatsApp broadcast list is assigned to the long experimental list qualtrics: binary variable indicating response mode (1 if Qualtrics, 0 if WhatsApp) T: treatment indicator, equals 1 if the WhatsApp broadcast list is assigned to the treatment group female: binary variable, equals 1 if the respondent is female c_Q4: survey question on factual knowledge about COVID-19 transmission or prevention c_Q5: survey question on factual knowledge about misinformation or fake cures Knowledge: z-score of the respondent's answers to the factual questions c_Q4_1: sub-item of Q4 (first option, coded 1 if correct, 0 otherwise) c_Q4_3: sub-item of Q4 (third option, coded 1 if correct, 0 otherwise) c_Q4_4: sub-item of Q4 (fourth option, coded 1 if correct, 0 otherwise) c_Q4_5: sub-item of Q4 (fifth option, coded 1 if correct, 0 otherwise) block: randomization block (grouping of broadcast lists created at similar times) length_subscribe: number of months the WhatsApp broadcast list had been active Week: indicator for intervention week (1 = distancing message, 2 = misinformation/cures message) response_rate: fraction of weekly responses coming from WhatsApp per person Week_id: numeric identifier for the week urban: binary variable, equals 1 if the individual lived in an urban district
natural_language_query: What is the effect of WhatsApp messages on individuals' knowledge about Covid19?
control_variables: urban, female, qualtrics

paper_name: Voting Made Safe and Easy: The Impact of e-voting on Citizen Perceptions
description: The dataset consists of individual-level responses collected during elections, focusing on voters' experiences and perceptions of different voting systems, along with contextual details about polling stations and election workers. On election day in Salta, 1,502 voters completed a structured questionnaire: 887 used electronic voting (e-voting), while the remainder voted with paper ballots. A total of 36 polling stations were sampled to reflect comparable socio-economic conditions. Participants were recruited using gender and age quotas, with the questionnaire tailored to their voting method. Additional information came from election workers and independent observers. The study assessed voter confidence in the process, views on secrecy and transparency, ease and speed of voting, poll worker qualifications, and preferences for electronic versus traditional votingparticularly within Argentina's split-ticket system. To facilitate interpretation, ordinal responses were recoded into binary indicators distinguishing positive from negative experiences across key outcomes: satisfaction, poll worker competence, ease and speed, candidate selection, confidence in counting, secrecy, and perceived election integrity. Data variables polling.place: Polling station (school) EV: Voting system (1 = electronic voting, 0 = traditional voting) age.group: Respondent age group educ: Education level of respondent male: Gender (1 = male, 0 = female) tech: Familiarity or comfort with technology; higher values indicate greater familiarity pol.info: Level of political information; higher values indicate more informed white.collar: Occupation type (1 = white-collar, 0 = otherwise) not.full.time: Employment status (1 = not full-time, 0 = full-time) capable.auth: Poll worker qualifications (1 = quite or very qualified, 0 otherwise) eval.voting: Overall assessment of voting experience (1 = very good, 0 otherwise) easy.voting: Ease of voting procedure (1 = very easy, 0 otherwise) sure.counted: Confidence that vote was counted accurately (1 = sure or very sure, 0 otherwise) conf.secret: Confidence in ballot secrecy (1 = confident or very confident, 0 otherwise) how.clean: Perception of election cleanness (1 = very or somewhat clean, 0 otherwise) speed: Speed of voting process (1 = quick or very quick, 0 otherwise) agree.evoting: Support for substituting traditional voting with e-voting (1 = agree or agree a lot, 0 otherwise) eselect.cand: Preference for selecting candidates (1 = electronically, 0 = by hand) propensity_score: Estimated propensity score for analysis
natural_language_query: Does electronic voting make it easier or harder for people to vote compared to paper ballots?
control_variables: age, age2, age3, educ, educ2, tech, tech2, pol_info, age_x_educ, age_x_tech, educ_x_pol, age_x_pol, tech_x_pol, white.collar, not.full.time, male

The study assessed voter confidence in the process, views on secrecy and transparency, ease and speed of voting, poll worker qualifications, and preferences for electronic versus traditional votingparticularly within Argentina's split-ticket system. To facilitate interpretation, ordinal responses were recoded into binary indicators distinguishing positive from negative experiences across key outcomes: satisfaction, poll worker competence, ease and speed, candidate selection, confidence in counting, secrecy, and perceived election integrity. Data variables polling.place: Polling station (school) EV: Voting system (1 = electronic voting, 0 = traditional voting) age.group: Respondent age group educ: Education level of respondent male: Gender (1 = male, 0 = female) tech: Familiarity or comfort with technology; higher values indicate greater familiarity pol.info: Level of political information; higher values indicate more informed white.collar: Occupation type (1 = white-collar, 0 = otherwise) not.full.time: Employment status (1 = not full-time, 0 = full-time) capable.auth: Poll worker qualifications (1 = quite or very qualified, 0 otherwise) eval.voting: Overall assessment of voting experience (1 = very good, 0 otherwise) easy.voting: Ease of voting procedure (1 = very easy, 0 otherwise) sure.counted: Confidence that vote was counted accurately (1 = sure or very sure, 0 otherwise) conf.secret: Confidence in ballot secrecy (1 = confident or very confident, 0 otherwise) how.clean: Perception of election cleanness (1 = very or somewhat clean, 0 otherwise) speed: Speed of voting process (1 = quick or very quick, 0 otherwise) agree.evoting: Support for substituting traditional voting with e-voting (1 = agree or agree a lot, 0 otherwise) eselect.cand: Preference for selecting candidates (1 = electronically, 0 = by hand) propensity_score: Estimated propensity score for analysis
natural_language_query: What is the effect of e-voting on voters' perception of poll worker qualification compared to traditional voting?

paper_name: The Effect of Property Assessment Reductions on Tax Delinquency and Tax Foreclosure
description: This dataset consists of parcel-year panel of Detroit residential properties from 2011–2019, combining assessor records, annual tax bills and delinquency amounts, millage rates, parcel characteristics, neighborhood identifiers, and validated sales information; each row is a parcel–year observation after filtering out zero tax bills and extreme tax‑bill changes to yield 1,612,270 residential parcel‑years under two acres. Variables: parcelnumber: Assessor parcel identifier used to link annual tax, assessment, and sales records across years and datasets. tax_year: Fiscal year associated with the parcel’s property tax record, used to construct annual panels and time indicators. tax_due: Current‑year delinquent amount owed for the parcel as recorded by the City of Detroit’s annual delinquency file (dollars). tax_due_lag1: Prior‑year delinquent amount owed, aligned to the parcel’s previous tax_year record (dollars). total_mills: Total statutory millage rate applied to the parcel that determines liability per $1,000 of taxable value. id: Internal analysis identifier for parcel–year observations to facilitate merging and indexing within the constructed panel. curclass: Current assessor property class code (e.g., residential, commercial, industrial) used to identify residential improved parcels. totalacres: Parcel land area in acres from assessor records. cioccupancy: Occupancy status code from city records indicating use/occupancy characteristics relevant for parcel profiling. pre: Principal Residence Exemption indicator equal to 1 for owner‑occupied “homestead” parcels and 0 otherwise. SEV: State Equalized Value, approximately 50 percent of market value and used alongside TV in assessment reporting (dollars). TV: Taxable Value subject to statutory growth caps and reset upon sale; multiplied by millage to compute tax bills (dollars). tract: Census tract identifier mapped to parcels for geographic referencing and neighborhood linkage. nhoodnum: Neighborhood numeric code per City of Detroit definitions used in mapping and summaries. nhood: Neighborhood name per City of Detroit definitions used in mapping and summaries. sale_price: Parcel’s arms‑length sale price after cleaning (valid sales identified via terms and winsorization of extremes) (dollars). sale_terms: Terms‑of‑sale code used to classify and retain valid arms‑length transactions in the sales subset. tax_bill: Annual property tax bill for the parcel calculated as TV times total millage per $1,000 (dollars; stored as dollars or $1,000s). tax_bill_diff: Year‑over‑year change in the parcel’s tax_bill measured in dollars (current minus prior year). tax_bill_l1: Prior‑year tax_bill aligned to the parcel’s current observation (dollars). tbill_ratio_lag0: Ratio of current‑year tax_bill to prior‑year tax_bill constructed from annual bills (unitless). tbill_ratio_lag1: Ratio of prior‑year tax_bill to the bill two years prior constructed from annual bills (unitles). dtbill_lag0: Percent change in tax_bill from prior year to current year, derived from annual bills (percent). dtbill_lag1: Prior‑year percent change in tax_bill, derived from lagged annual bills (percent). tbill_l1_1000: Prior‑year tax bill expressed in thousands of dollars for scaling in analyses (dollars per $1,000). tb_neg: Indicator equal to 1 if the parcel experienced a negative change in tax_bill in the current year and 0 otherwise. apartment_2015: Flag identifying parcels classified as apartment/multifamily in the 2015 assessor snapshot for property‑type stratification. dep_dummy_100: Indicator equal to 1 if current‑year back taxes owed exceed $100 and 0 otherwise (constructed from annual delinquency amounts). dep_dummy_200: Indicator equal to 1 if current‑year back taxes owed exceed $200 and 0 otherwise (primary delinquency threshold in the main data). dep_dummy_300: Indicator equal to 1 if current‑year back taxes owed exceed $300 and 0 otherwise. dep_dummy_400: Indicator equal to 1 if current‑year back taxes owed exceed $400 and 0 otherwise.
natural_language_query: How does a $1,000 increase in last year’s property tax bill affect the probability that a residential parcel is tax‑delinquent this year, holding year effects, total millage, and principal‑residence status constant?
control_variables: total_mills, pre

paper_name: The Impact of Recentralization on Public Services: A Difference-in-Differences Analysis of the Abolition of Elected Councils in Vietnam
description: This dataset is a commune–year panel for rural Vietnam built from the 2006, 2008, and 2010 Vietnam Household Living Standards Survey (VHLSS) commune questionnaires and merged with district– and province–level identifiers for the District People’s Council (DPC) abolition pilot. Each observation corresponds to a rural commune in a given survey year, with variables describing geography, survey timing, infrastructure, public services, agriculture, nonfarm activity, migration, credit access, health and education facilities, land use, sectoral structure, and treatment status in the recentralization experiment. Variables: tinh: Province code identifying the province in which the commune is located, used to link communes to provincial characteristics and the treatment assignment strata.​ huyen: District code indicating the district (second‑tier unit) in which the commune resides, which is the level at which District People’s Councils were abolished in treated areas.​ xa: Commune code identifying the basic local administrative unit observed in the VHLSS commune survey.​ madt: Survey or commune identifier from the VHLSS used to uniquely index communes within survey waves and to merge across questionnaire modules.​ ngaydt / thangdt: Day and month of the commune interview date, recording when the VHLSS commune questionnaire was administered in the field.​ ngayct / thangct: Day and month of completion for the commune questionnaire or related verification, capturing timing of finalization of commune‑level data.​ m1c1–m1c10, m1c11a–m1c11c, m1c12a–m1c12c, m1c13–m1c15: Original VHLSS module‑1 commune checklist items capturing basic commune characteristics and public services (e.g., infrastructure, social programs, local projects), coded as binary indicators or shares and later combined into sector‑specific indices (infrastructure, agricultural services, health, education, communications, household business support).​ m3c1–m3c5, m3c2, m3c2a1–m3c2a3, m3c3, m3c4a–m3c4c, m3c4a1–m3c4a3, m3c5: Original VHLSS module‑3 items on nonfarm employment, local economic activity, and social problems, providing commune‑level indicators of nonfarm jobs, business conditions, and related constraints used in constructing household‑business development outcomes.​ roadvmonth: Measure of road or transport–related investment or maintenance at the commune level (e.g., months with road work or road access), capturing intensity of road service over the year.​ totalhh: Total number of households in the commune, used to construct household shares for service coverage (e.g., share of households receiving agricultural extension or health fee support).​ improve: Indicator summarizing whether overall living standards or socio‑economic conditions in the commune have improved over a recent period as reported by local authorities.​ poorhh: Number or share of poor households in the commune according to official poverty classification, providing a commune‑level poverty rate.​ geogra: Categorical or coded measure of the commune’s geographic type (e.g., lowland, highland, coastal, remote), used as a control for structural conditions in service delivery.​ pro135: Indicator for whether the commune is covered by Vietnam’s Program 135 or other national poverty‑targeted programs, capturing exposure to special development support.​ remotecom: Indicator for whether the commune is classified as remote or especially difficult, reflecting geographic disadvantage and higher costs of service provision.​ credithh: Number or share of households receiving formal or semi‑formal credit support, used as an outcome in the household‑business development index.​ povrate: Commune‑level poverty rate constructed from poor households over total households or from official statistics, summarizing local deprivation.​ pro1–pro6: Set of indicators capturing the presence or implementation of different centrally funded socio‑economic projects or programs in the commune (e.g., transport, health, education, poverty alleviation), used to characterize local project activity.​ agrext / dagrext: Indicators for the presence of agricultural extension services in the commune and changes over time (e.g., availability of extension staff or centers), feeding into the agricultural services index.​ roadv / goodroadv / droadv: Measures of village‑level road access and quality, including whether villages are connected by all‑weather roads, the share of “good” roads, and changes in road conditions across years.​ transport: Indicator for whether the commune has public transport services (e.g., bus or other collective transport), one of the treated infrastructure outcomes.​ post / market / electricity / culture / broadcast / irrigation: Binary or categorical indicators for the presence of key public facilities in the commune—post offices, markets, electricity grid connections, cultural houses, broadcast stations, and irrigation systems—used as inputs to infrastructure and communications indices.​ prischool / lseschool / useschool / kgarten: Indicators for the existence or accessibility of primary, lower‑secondary, upper‑secondary schools, and kindergartens in the commune, forming the base of the education services index.​ nonfarm / nonfarme: Measures of nonfarm employment and nonfarm enterprises in the commune, capturing diversification of local livelihoods away from agriculture.​ emproblem: Indicator summarizing key employment problems in the commune (e.g., underemployment, lack of local jobs) as reported by commune leaders.​ migration_in / migration_out: Commune‑level counts or indicators for in‑migration and out‑migration, reflecting population flows and labor mobility.​ population: Total population of the commune, used to scale services and to construct population density.​ rm2c7a–rm2c7g (rm2c7a–rm2c7f, rm2c7g): Group of items capturing specific social or economic problems reported by commune authorities (e.g., crime, environmental issues, social evils), providing contextual information on local challenges.​ villbusi / numbusi: Indicators for whether the commune has village‑level household businesses and the total number of household businesses, used in the household business development index.​ agrrise: Indicator for whether agricultural production in the commune has recently risen, reflecting local economic trends in farming.​ cleanwater / tapwater: Indicators for access to clean water sources and piped or tap water in the commune, often used as complementary infrastructure or health‑related outcomes.​ agrvisit / plant_s / animal_s: Measures of agricultural extension intensity—such as the number of extension visits (agrvisit) and the presence of plant and animal husbandry support services—capturing the depth of agricultural support.​ polluted: Indicator for whether the commune reports pollution problems, capturing environmental conditions that may co‑vary with infrastructure and industrialization.​ nfworkers: Number of nonfarm workers in the commune workforce, summarizing structural change in local employment.​ hecenter1–hecenter5, hecenter: Indicators for the existence of different types of local health centers or facilities and an aggregate indicator summarizing whether any such health center is present, feeding into the health services index.​ d_hecenter1–d_hecenter5: Change indicators tracking whether specific types of health centers have appeared or disappeared between survey waves, capturing dynamics of health infrastructure.​ lender1–lender7, lender1a–lender6a: Indicators for the presence or use of multiple types of credit providers in the commune (e.g., different institutional or informal lenders) and their activity, providing a detailed picture of local credit markets for households and small firms.​ d_lender1–d_lender7, d_lender1a–d_lender6a: Change variables indicating expansions or contractions in access to the corresponding lender types over time, used to study evolution of credit access.​ land1–land5: Areas or shares of different categories of agricultural land in the commune (e.g., by land type or use class), summarizing the structure of local land resources.​ land1_irr / land2_irr: Portions of specific land categories under irrigation, measuring the intensity of irrigation infrastructure across agricultural land.​ land1_cer–land5_cer: Areas of specific land categories devoted to cereal or staple crops, characterizing local cropping patterns.​ vmarket1–vmarket3: Indicators for the existence of various kinds of markets within commune villages (e.g., daily, periodic, or wholesale), used in the household business development index.​ vpeocom / vpost / vbank: Indicators for the presence of people’s committees, post offices, and bank or credit institutions within villages, capturing intra‑commune spatial distribution of administrative and financial services.​ dmarket1–dmarket3 / dpeocom / dpost / dbank: Change indicators for village‑level markets, administrative offices, post offices, and banks, reflecting expansions or contractions in local service coverage over time.​ dtown: Indicator for proximity to or inclusion of a district town within the commune, capturing centrality in the district’s spatial hierarchy.​ timemarket1–timemarket3: Travel time measures from the commune or villages to different market types, providing continuous measures of market access.​ v_prischool / v_lseschool / v_useschool: Indicators for the presence of primary, lower‑secondary, and upper‑secondary schools at the village level, refining the education access measures beyond commune‑level presence.​ s_prischool / s_lseschool / s_useschool: Measures of schooling capacity or scale (e.g., number of classrooms or students) for primary, lower‑secondary, and upper‑secondary schools in the commune.​ d_prischool / d_lseschool / d_useschool: Change indicators showing whether different school levels have opened or closed between survey waves.​ year: Calendar year of the VHLSS commune survey (2006, 2008, 2010), forming the time dimension of the panel.​ reg8: Eight‑region stratification code (e.g., Northern Mountains, Red River Delta, Central Coast, etc.) used to control for macro‑regional differences and to mirror the stratified design of the DPC abolition pilot.​ commune: String or numeric identifier for the commune, harmonized to track the same locality across survey years.​ province_name / district_name / tentinh / tinh_new: Text and alternative numeric codes for provinces and districts, allowing transparent labeling of administrative units and alignment with official administrative changes.​ treatment: Indicator equal to 1 for communes in districts where District People’s Councils were abolished in the national pilot and 0 for communes in control districts, serving as the main treatment variable in the difference‑in‑differences design.​ nongnghiep / congnghiep / dichvu: Province‑ or district‑level measures of agricultural, industrial, and service output or employment linked to communes, summarizing sectoral structure of the local economy.​ laodong: Total labor force in the province or district associated with the commune, used to compute labor‑force‑based ratios.​ danso: Total population at the higher administrative level, complementing the commune‑level population measure and providing a basis for relative shares.​ time: Analysis time variable (e.g., coded 0/1 for pre‑ and post‑treatment) used in constructing interaction terms for difference‑in‑differences estimation.​ totalland / sland1–sland5: Total agricultural land area in the commune and corresponding areas allocated to the same land categories as land1–land5, often expressed in standardized units to compare across communes.​ area / lnarea: Commune land area in physical units and its natural logarithm, used to control for size and to compute densities.​ popden / lnpopden: Population density (population per area) and its logarithm, capturing how densely settled the commune is.​ lnnongnghiep / lncongnghiep / lndichvu: Natural logs of agricultural, industrial, and service output at the province or district level, used as covariates summarizing economic scale by sector.​ lnlaodong / lndanso: Natural logs of labor force and population for the higher‑level administrative unit, providing scale controls in regressions.​ rnongnghiep / rcongnghiep / rdichvu / rlaodong: Relative or share measures (e.g., ratios) of agriculture, industry, services, and labor force in the province or district, capturing economic structure rather than levels.​ steering: Indicator for whether the commune lies in a province directly overseen by the national steering committee for the DPC removal pilot, allowing sensitivity checks for central oversight.​ surveyed: Indicator for whether the province containing the commune was additionally visited and surveyed by the Ministry of Home Affairs evaluation teams, used to test for Hawthorne‑type monitoring effects.​
natural_language_query: What is the effect of the 2009 recentralization on whether a commune’s main road is usable all year?
control_variables: Inarea, Indanso, city, reg8

paper_name: Vouchers for Private Schooling in Colombia: Evidence from a Randomized Natural Experiment
description: This dataset is an individual-level microdata file on applicants to Colombia’s PACES secondary-school voucher program, combining lottery assignment records, follow-up survey responses, and achievement test participation indicators for cohorts in Bogotá (1995, 1997) and Jamundí (1993). It is structured to support analysis of schooling trajectories, private versus public school attendance, household background, labor and family formation outcomes, and test-taking behavior for voucher-eligible youth, without embedding specific modeling choices. ID: Numeric identifier linking each record to the original PACES applicant list, stable within the file and used to join administrative lottery status, survey outcomes, and test participation.​​ BOG95SMP: Indicator for membership in the Bogotá 1995 applicant cohort analysis sample (1 = Bogotá 1995 cohort, 0 otherwise), aligning each individual with that specific city-year sampling frame.​​ BOG97SMP: Indicator for membership in the Bogotá 1997 applicant cohort analysis sample (1 = Bogotá 1997 cohort, 0 otherwise), distinguishing this later application year within Bogotá.​​ JAM93SMP: Indicator for membership in the Jamundí 1993 applicant cohort analysis sample (1 = Jamundí 1993 cohort, 0 otherwise), identifying applicants from the suburban Cali site.​​ SEX: Binary sex indicator at the individual level, derived from survey or name-based coding and used for gender-disaggregated description and outcome analysis.​​ AGE: Applicant’s age in completed years, typically imputed from the Colombian national ID at the time of program application and used as a key demographic control.​​ AGE2: Square of age, capturing non-linear relationships between age and schooling outcomes or other behaviors such as work and marriage.​​ HSVISIT: Indicator for interview mode (1 = household visit, 0 = telephone interview), reflecting fieldwork logistics and used to control for mode-related response differences.​​ SCYFNSH: Measure summarizing schooling completion within the secondary cycle (for example, highest grade completed by survey date), constructed from detailed grade histories.​​ INSCHL: Binary indicator for current school enrollment at the survey date (1 = currently in school, 0 = not enrolled), derived from self-reported enrollment status.​​ PRSCH_C: Binary indicator for current private secondary school attendance (1 = enrolled in a private school at survey time, 0 = public school or not enrolled), used to describe current sector of schooling.​​ PRSCHA_1: Indicator capturing private-school attendance at a key grade or early stage of secondary schooling (1 = attended a participating private secondary school at that stage, 0 otherwise), constructed from retrospective schooling histories.​​ PRSCHA_2: Complementary indicator for private-school attendance at an additional grade or later stage of secondary schooling, allowing distinctions between initial and subsequent private enrollment episodes.​​ VOUCH0: Binary lottery-assignment indicator for the PACES voucher offer (1 = offered a PACES scholarship via lottery, 0 = not offered), taken from administrative lottery records and used to distinguish voucher winners from losers.​​ BOG95ASD: Indicator for inclusion in the Bogotá 1995 achievement-test subsample (1 = invited/test sample for Bogotá 1995, 0 otherwise), identifying records with linked standardized test scores.​​ BOG97ASD: Indicator for inclusion in any Bogotá 1997 achievement-related subsample if present, parallel in structure to BOG95ASD but for the 1997 cohort.​​ JAM93ASD: Indicator for inclusion in any Jamundí 1993 achievement-test subsample if collected, flagging Jamundí test-takers within the broader applicant frame.​​ DBOGOTA: City dummy for Bogotá (1 = Bogotá, 0 = other sites), aligning individuals with the capital city context for descriptive and regression controls.​​ DJAMUNDI: City dummy for Jamundí (1 = Jamundí, 0 = other sites), capturing the suburban Cali site as distinct from Bogotá.​​ D1995: Application-year dummy (1 = applied in 1995, 0 otherwise), marking the Bogotá 1995 cohort in pooled analyses across years.​​ D1997: Application-year dummy (1 = applied in 1997, 0 otherwise), identifying the later Bogotá cohort in multi-cohort analyses.​​ D1993: Application-year dummy (1 = applied in 1993, 0 otherwise), corresponding to the Jamundí 1993 cohort.​​ RESPONSE: Indicator that a valid 1998 follow-up survey interview was completed for the applicant (1 = interviewed, 0 = in sampling frame but not interviewed), capturing differential follow-up.​​ TEST_TAK: Indicator that the applicant took the 1999 standardized achievement test (1 = test-taker, 0 = not tested), linking survey records to test-score availability.​​ SEX_NAME: Auxiliary indicator of sex coded from first names in the application list, used to impute sex where direct survey information is missing.​​ SVY: Survey-form or instrument indicator that flags the questionnaire version or survey group, enabling control for minor differences in question wording or survey conditions.​​ PHONE: Indicator for having a telephone contact at application (1 = phone number recorded, 0 = no phone), reflecting contactability and part of the implicit sampling frame for telephone interviews.​​ DAREA1–DAREA19: Set of neighborhood or large-area dummies for Bogotá (and analogous groupings where applicable), capturing 19 residential areas used as geographic strata or controls.​​ DMONTH1–DMONTH12: Interview-month dummies (1 = interviewed in the corresponding calendar month, 0 otherwise), representing survey timing over the fieldwork period.​​ BOG95: Indicator for being in the Bogotá 1995 cohort in contexts where this cohort is contrasted with others, often overlapping conceptually with BOG95SMP but used in some outcome subsamples.​​ BOG97: Indicator for being in the Bogotá 1997 cohort, similarly used as a cohort marker in pooled models.​​ MOM_SCH: Mother’s highest completed grade of schooling in years, as reported in the survey, serving as a parental human-capital measure.​​ MOM_AGE: Mother’s age in years at the time of survey, capturing parental lifecycle stage.​​ MOM_MW: Indicator that the mother’s wage exceeds a threshold multiple of the minimum wage (for example, more than two minimum wages), proxying maternal earnings capacity.​​ DAD_SCH: Father’s highest completed grade of schooling in years, measuring paternal education as part of family background.​​ DAD_AGE: Father’s age in years at the time of survey, capturing paternal lifecycle stage.​​ DAD_MW: Indicator that the father’s wage exceeds a threshold multiple of the minimum wage, summarizing paternal earnings potential.​​ SEX2: Harmonized or alternative sex indicator used in the main analytic regressions, combining name-based and survey-based sex coding where necessary.​​ STRATA1–STRATA6: Set of dummies for the six official Colombian socioeconomic residential strata, derived from utility-bill based classification in the application and used to capture household socioeconomic status.​​ STRATAMS: Indicator for missing or unspecified socioeconomic stratum, preserving individuals with incomplete strata information in analyses.​​ REPT6: Indicator that the applicant repeated sixth grade at least once, summarizing early grade repetition at the entry to secondary schooling.​​ TOTSCYRS: Total number of calendar years spent in school since the time of application, aggregating enrollment histories into a duration-style schooling exposure measure.​​ HASCHILD: Indicator that the applicant has at least one child at the time of survey, measuring early fertility outcomes.​​ MARRIED: Indicator that the applicant is married or cohabiting with a partner at the time of survey, capturing early union formation.​​ WORKING: Binary indicator that the applicant is engaged in paid work at the time of survey, summarizing labor-force participation.​​ REPT: Indicator that the applicant has repeated at least one grade after the lottery, capturing any post-application grade repetition.​​ NREPT: Count of grades repeated since the lottery, providing a more granular measure of cumulative repetition.​​ FINISH6: Indicator that the applicant has successfully completed grade 6, the first year of Colombian secondary school.​​ FINISH7: Indicator that the applicant has successfully completed grade 7, reflecting progression through early secondary schooling.​​ FINISH8: Indicator that the applicant has successfully completed grade 8, used to summarize lower-secondary completion.​​ SEX_MISS: Indicator that sex information is missing in the primary coding, flagging records relying on imputation or with unresolved sex classification.​​ USNGSCH: Indicator that the applicant is using any scholarship (PACES voucher or other scholarship) in the survey year, capturing current scholarship utilization.​​ HOURSUM: Total number of hours worked per week by the applicant at the time of survey, computed from reported work schedules and used to quantify labor supply.​​ TAB3SMPL: Indicator that an observation is included in the analysis sample corresponding to a specific table (for example, Table 3) in the original study, marking the main balanced analytic subsample.​​ WORKING3: Alternative working-status indicator defined for the Table 3 sample or using a particular coding of work (e.g., excluding very low-intensity work), complementing WORKING.
natural_language_query: Does winning a lottery affect the number of hours of work?
control_variables: AGE, AGE2, SEX2, PHONE, DMONTH1-DMONTH11, STRATA1-STRATA5, BOG97SMP, JAM93SMP

paper_name: Vouchers for Private Schooling in Colombia: Evidence from a Randomized Natural Experiment
description: This dataset is an individual-level microdata file on applicants to Colombia’s PACES secondary-school voucher program, combining lottery assignment records, follow-up survey responses, and achievement test participation indicators for cohorts in Bogotá (1995, 1997) and Jamundí (1993). It is structured to support analysis of schooling trajectories, private versus public school attendance, household background, labor and family formation outcomes, and test-taking behavior for voucher-eligible youth, without embedding specific modeling choices. ID: Numeric identifier linking each record to the original PACES applicant list, stable within the file and used to join administrative lottery status, survey outcomes, and test participation.​​ BOG95SMP: Indicator for membership in the Bogotá 1995 applicant cohort analysis sample (1 = Bogotá 1995 cohort, 0 otherwise), aligning each individual with that specific city-year sampling frame.​​ BOG97SMP: Indicator for membership in the Bogotá 1997 applicant cohort analysis sample (1 = Bogotá 1997 cohort, 0 otherwise), distinguishing this later application year within Bogotá.​​ JAM93SMP: Indicator for membership in the Jamundí 1993 applicant cohort analysis sample (1 = Jamundí 1993 cohort, 0 otherwise), identifying applicants from the suburban Cali site.​​ SEX: Binary sex indicator at the individual level, derived from survey or name-based coding and used for gender-disaggregated description and outcome analysis.​​ AGE: Applicant’s age in completed years, typically imputed from the Colombian national ID at the time of program application and used as a key demographic control.​​ AGE2: Square of age, capturing non-linear relationships between age and schooling outcomes or other behaviors such as work and marriage.​​ HSVISIT: Indicator for interview mode (1 = household visit, 0 = telephone interview), reflecting fieldwork logistics and used to control for mode-related response differences.​​ SCYFNSH: Measure summarizing schooling completion within the secondary cycle (for example, highest grade completed by survey date), constructed from detailed grade histories.​​ INSCHL: Binary indicator for current school enrollment at the survey date (1 = currently in school, 0 = not enrolled), derived from self-reported enrollment status.​​ PRSCH_C: Binary indicator for current private secondary school attendance (1 = enrolled in a private school at survey time, 0 = public school or not enrolled), used to describe current sector of schooling.​​ PRSCHA_1: Indicator capturing private-school attendance at a key grade or early stage of secondary schooling (1 = attended a participating private secondary school at that stage, 0 otherwise), constructed from retrospective schooling histories.​​ PRSCHA_2: Complementary indicator for private-school attendance at an additional grade or later stage of secondary schooling, allowing distinctions between initial and subsequent private enrollment episodes.​​ VOUCH0: Binary lottery-assignment indicator for the PACES voucher offer (1 = offered a PACES scholarship via lottery, 0 = not offered), taken from administrative lottery records and used to distinguish voucher winners from losers.​​ BOG95ASD: Indicator for inclusion in the Bogotá 1995 achievement-test subsample (1 = invited/test sample for Bogotá 1995, 0 otherwise), identifying records with linked standardized test scores.​​ BOG97ASD: Indicator for inclusion in any Bogotá 1997 achievement-related subsample if present, parallel in structure to BOG95ASD but for the 1997 cohort.​​ JAM93ASD: Indicator for inclusion in any Jamundí 1993 achievement-test subsample if collected, flagging Jamundí test-takers within the broader applicant frame.​​ DBOGOTA: City dummy for Bogotá (1 = Bogotá, 0 = other sites), aligning individuals with the capital city context for descriptive and regression controls.​​ DJAMUNDI: City dummy for Jamundí (1 = Jamundí, 0 = other sites), capturing the suburban Cali site as distinct from Bogotá.​​ D1995: Application-year dummy (1 = applied in 1995, 0 otherwise), marking the Bogotá 1995 cohort in pooled analyses across years.​​ D1997: Application-year dummy (1 = applied in 1997, 0 otherwise), identifying the later Bogotá cohort in multi-cohort analyses.​​ D1993: Application-year dummy (1 = applied in 1993, 0 otherwise), corresponding to the Jamundí 1993 cohort.​​ RESPONSE: Indicator that a valid 1998 follow-up survey interview was completed for the applicant (1 = interviewed, 0 = in sampling frame but not interviewed), capturing differential follow-up.​​ TEST_TAK: Indicator that the applicant took the 1999 standardized achievement test (1 = test-taker, 0 = not tested), linking survey records to test-score availability.​​ SEX_NAME: Auxiliary indicator of sex coded from first names in the application list, used to impute sex where direct survey information is missing.​​ SVY: Survey-form or instrument indicator that flags the questionnaire version or survey group, enabling control for minor differences in question wording or survey conditions.​​ PHONE: Indicator for having a telephone contact at application (1 = phone number recorded, 0 = no phone), reflecting contactability and part of the implicit sampling frame for telephone interviews.​​ DAREA1–DAREA19: Set of neighborhood or large-area dummies for Bogotá (and analogous groupings where applicable), capturing 19 residential areas used as geographic strata or controls.​​ DMONTH1–DMONTH12: Interview-month dummies (1 = interviewed in the corresponding calendar month, 0 otherwise), representing survey timing over the fieldwork period.​​ BOG95: Indicator for being in the Bogotá 1995 cohort in contexts where this cohort is contrasted with others, often overlapping conceptually with BOG95SMP but used in some outcome subsamples.​​ BOG97: Indicator for being in the Bogotá 1997 cohort, similarly used as a cohort marker in pooled models.​​ MOM_SCH: Mother’s highest completed grade of schooling in years, as reported in the survey, serving as a parental human-capital measure.​​ MOM_AGE: Mother’s age in years at the time of survey, capturing parental lifecycle stage.​​ MOM_MW: Indicator that the mother’s wage exceeds a threshold multiple of the minimum wage (for example, more than two minimum wages), proxying maternal earnings capacity.​​ DAD_SCH: Father’s highest completed grade of schooling in years, measuring paternal education as part of family background.​​ DAD_AGE: Father’s age in years at the time of survey, capturing paternal lifecycle stage.​​ DAD_MW: Indicator that the father’s wage exceeds a threshold multiple of the minimum wage, summarizing paternal earnings potential.​​ SEX2: Harmonized or alternative sex indicator used in the main analytic regressions, combining name-based and survey-based sex coding where necessary.​​ STRATA1–STRATA6: Set of dummies for the six official Colombian socioeconomic residential strata, derived from utility-bill based classification in the application and used to capture household socioeconomic status.​​ STRATAMS: Indicator for missing or unspecified socioeconomic stratum, preserving individuals with incomplete strata information in analyses.​​ REPT6: Indicator that the applicant repeated sixth grade at least once, summarizing early grade repetition at the entry to secondary schooling.​​ TOTSCYRS: Total number of calendar years spent in school since the time of application, aggregating enrollment histories into a duration-style schooling exposure measure.​​ HASCHILD: Indicator that the applicant has at least one child at the time of survey, measuring early fertility outcomes.​​ MARRIED: Indicator that the applicant is married or cohabiting with a partner at the time of survey, capturing early union formation.​​ WORKING: Binary indicator that the applicant is engaged in paid work at the time of survey, summarizing labor-force participation.​​ REPT: Indicator that the applicant has repeated at least one grade after the lottery, capturing any post-application grade repetition.​​ NREPT: Count of grades repeated since the lottery, providing a more granular measure of cumulative repetition.​​ FINISH6: Indicator that the applicant has successfully completed grade 6, the first year of Colombian secondary school.​​ FINISH7: Indicator that the applicant has successfully completed grade 7, reflecting progression through early secondary schooling.​​ FINISH8: Indicator that the applicant has successfully completed grade 8, used to summarize lower-secondary completion.​​ SEX_MISS: Indicator that sex information is missing in the primary coding, flagging records relying on imputation or with unresolved sex classification.​​ USNGSCH: Indicator that the applicant is using any scholarship (PACES voucher or other scholarship) in the survey year, capturing current scholarship utilization.​​ HOURSUM: Total number of hours worked per week by the applicant at the time of survey, computed from reported work schedules and used to quantify labor supply.​​ TAB3SMPL: Indicator that an observation is included in the analysis sample corresponding to a specific table (for example, Table 3) in the original study, marking the main balanced analytic subsample.​​ WORKING3: Alternative working-status indicator defined for the Table 3 sample or using a particular coding of work (e.g., excluding very low-intensity work), complementing WORKING.
natural_language_query: Does winning a lottery affect the likelihood of being in the labor force?
control_variables: AGE, AGE2, SEX2, PHONE, DMONTH1-DMONTH11, STRATA1-STRATA5, BOG97SMP, JAM93SMP
