paper_name: A Call to Arms: How Rebel Groups Choose Their Recruitment Appeals
description: This dataset is a cross-sectional rebel-group-level file that integrates original measures of recruitment appeals from the Rebel Appeals and Incentives Dataset (RAID) with standardized indicators of rebel ideology, organizational features, and country-level context for 232 rebel movements active worldwide between 1989 and 2011. Each record corresponds to a distinct rebel organization and captures both the breadth and composition of its grievance-based recruitment appeals, as well as its ideological profile, strength, territorial control, ethnic composition, and the regime and economic environment in which it operates. Variable descriptions: new_side_b_id: Numeric group identifier that uniquely references each rebel organization in the merged file, harmonizing the RAID units with the underlying non-state actor and replication identifiers used for statistical analysis.​ ccode: Numeric country code indicating the primary state within which the rebel group is active, enabling linkage to country-level democracy and GDP covariates and the clustering of standard errors by conflict country.​ ideol_ord: Ordinal indicator capturing the group’s core ideology type as used in the models (e.g., distinguishing radical Islamist from other ideological families) to operationalize the main explanatory contrast in the paper.​ other_rel_appeals: Dichotomous RAID-based indicator coded 1 if the group sometimes employs recruitment appeals to non-Islamist religious ideologies (e.g., generic religious or non-radical faith-based claims), and 0 otherwise.​ left_appeals: Binary variable denoting whether the group recruits using left-wing or communist ideological appeals, such as references to Marxist principles or anti-capitalist class struggle.​ anti_resource_appeals: Indicator coded 1 when rebel recruitment materials highlight opposition to the exploitation of local resources by external actors, including grievances about plunder or unequal resource extraction.​ gov_violence_appeals: Binary measure for appeals centered on violent government repression and human rights abuses, where recruitment narratives emphasize state-perpetrated killings, torture, or indiscriminate attacks.​ feminist_appeals: Indicator for appeals invoking women’s rights or gender inequality as a recruitment theme, such as mobilizing against gendered exclusion or violence.​ other_appeals: Catch-all binary category capturing miscellaneous recruitment appeals that do not fit the primary ideological or grievance types but nonetheless appear as recurring frames in the group’s propaganda. ethnic_nat_appeals: Dichotomous RAID measure indicating whether the group mobilizes recruits using ethnonationalist or regional grievances, such as discrimination against a specific ethnic community or demands for national self-determination.​ anti_intervention_appeals: Binary indicator coded 1 when groups employ recruitment appeals opposing foreign military intervention or occupation, including denunciations of external troops or international coalitions.​ gov_grievance_appeals: Variable marking general anti-government grievance appeals, where recruitment emphasizes corruption, misrule, or broad political injustices without being limited to a single policy issue.​ multi_ethnic: Dichotomous measure from RAID indicating whether the group’s membership is multi-ethnic, capturing heterogeneity in the ethnic background of recruits rather than whether ethnicity is the explicit basis of mobilization.​ secessionist: Binary indicator of whether the organization has secessionist aims, that is, whether it seeks to create an independent state separate from the existing central government.​ reb_strength_ord: Ordinal measure of relative rebel strength taken from the NSA dataset, capturing expert assessments of whether the group is weaker, roughly equal, or stronger relative to government forces.​ name: Text string with the full or commonly used name of the rebel organization, preserving interpretable labels alongside numeric identifiers for substantive interpretation and replication.​ multi_appeals: Binary summary indicator coded 1 if the group uses two or more distinct recruitment appeals (across the RAID dimensions), operationalizing whether recruitment is diversified versus narrow.​ terr_cont: Dichotomous measure for whether the group controls territory at any point, indicating de facto governance or sustained physical control of areas as captured in the NSA data.​ any_nr_binary: Indicator for whether the group exploited any natural resources (e.g., lootable or extractive commodities) during its life, derived from the Rebel Contraband Dataset and collapsed into a yes/no measure.​ appeals_count: Count variable measuring the total number of distinct recruitment appeals coded for the group across the RAID dimensions, ranging from 0 (no grievance-based appeals, only material incentives) to higher values for groups with more diverse appeals.​ other_group_binary: Binary measure capturing whether another rebel group was present in the same country when this group entered the armed conflict dataset, providing a simple indicator of inter-rebel competition.​ left_wing: Dichotomous indicator (from WARD/FORGE) for whether the organization has a communist or broader left-wing founding ideology, used both as a control and for constructing alternative measures of ideological diversity.​ supporttype_funds_rebel: Binary variable indicating whether the group received financial support from external actors (e.g., state sponsors or foreign patrons), based on external support data on rebel funding.​ radical_islamist: Core binary explanatory variable coded 1 for groups with a radical Islamist ideology—those espousing goals such as establishing an Islamic state, enforcing religious law, or defending Islam—and 0 otherwise.​ foreign_f: Dichotomous indicator of whether the group recruits foreign fighters, based on external foreign-fighter datasets and used to test how internationalization of recruitment conditions appeal diversity.​ v2x_polyarchy: Continuous country-level democracy score (polyarchy index) for the group’s main country, capturing the extent of electoral competition and participation and serving as a control for regime type.​ mean_log10_gdp_pc: Continuous measure of average logged GDP per capita in the group’s host country over its active period, capturing income levels and included as a macroeconomic control.​ group_age: Numeric variable measuring the age or duration of the group (e.g., years active), used as a control to account for the possibility that older organizations have had more time to diversify appeals.​ ideology_forge_count: Count of the number of distinct founding ideologies attributed to the group in the FORGE dataset (e.g., religious, nationalist, left-wing), used in robustness checks on broader ideological diversity.​ incompatible_appeals: Binary measure constructed by examining all pairwise correlations among appeals in RAID and coding 1 if the group employs at least one pair of appeals that are negatively and significantly associated in the full sample, indicating that it combines appeals most groups avoid mixing.​ post_2003: Dichotomous indicator taking value 1 for groups active after 2003, capturing the post–Iraq invasion period in which transnational jihadist dynamics and perceptions of threats to Islam intensified.​ ideology_count: Count variable summarizing the number of ideologies a group represents across external ideology datasets (e.g., socialism, Islamism, nationalism), used in robustness checks on ideological diversification beyond recruitment appeals.​ appeals_count_restrict: Alternative, more restrictive count of recruitment appeals that excludes appeals corresponding to the group’s parent ideology (e.g., omitting Islamist appeals for Islamist groups), used to test whether results hold when focusing on “non-core” grievances.​ multi_appeals_restrict: Binary version of the restrictive count, coded 1 if the group makes two or more non-parent appeals, allowing analyses of diversified grievance framing net of primary ideology.​ year_start: Calendar year in which the group first appears in the armed conflict or non-state actor data, anchoring the onset of its conflict activity and the period over which contextual covariates are averaged or coded.​ year_end: Calendar year in which the group exits the dataset (e.g., due to dissolution, defeat, or end of recorded activity), marking the end of its observed life span for the purposes of computing group age and averaging country-level variables.​
natural_language_query: Does being a radical Islamist group causally increase the number of recruitment appeals they make?
control_variables: secessionist, left_wing, multi_ethnic, any_nr_binary, supporttype_funds_rebel, group_age, reb_strength_ord, terr_cont, other_group_binary, post_2003, v2x_polyarchy, mean_log10_gdp_pc

paper_name: Experimental evidence that changing beliefs about mask efficacy and social norms increase mask wearing for COVID-19 risk reduction: Results from the United States and Italy
description: The randomized experiment examines the causal relationship between beliefs, social norms, and reported intentions to engage in mask promoting behavior. Subjects are randomly assigned to a control group, a "Mask Protects You" group, and a "Mask Protects Others" group. The control group reads a message unrelated to the experiment, the "Mask Protects You" group reads a message about how masks protect the wearer, and the "Mask Protects Others" group reads a message about how masks protect others. After the treatment, subjects are asked about their beliefs about masks. They then read three vignette scenarios, taking place at an ATM, in a park or in a meeting in their neighborhood. In the first scenario, they are asked about what they would do when they have forgotten to bring their mask. In the second scenario, they are asked about what they would do if someone else was not wearing their mask properly. In the third scenario, they are asked about their evaluation of someone who took action against someone not wearing their mask properly. Variables in the dataset: age: age of the subject. female: whether the subject is female. lucid_hhi: household income. lucid_incmissing: whether the subject's income is missing. ethnicity: ethnicity of the subject. education: education level of the subject. workstatus: work status of the subject. fluvaccine: whether the subject has received the flu vaccine. pool_self_scenario_atm: whether the first vignette scenario takes place at an ATM. pool_self_scenario_meet: whether the first vignette scenario takes place in a meeting in the neighborhood. pool_other_scenario_atm: whether the second vignette scenario takes place at an ATM. pool_other_scenario_meet: whether the second vignette scenario takes place in a meeting in the neighborhood. partisanship_1: whether the subject is a strong democrat. partisanship_2: whether the subject is a democrat. partisanship_3: whether the subject is a democrat lean. partisanship_4: whether the subject is an independent. partisanship_5: whether the subject is a republican lean. partisanship_6: whether the subject is a republican. partisanship_7: whether the subject is a strong republican. T_mask_protectyou: whether the subject was in the "Mask Protects You" group. T_mask_protectother: whether the subject was in the "Mask Protects Others" group. mskblfs_prtctothers: whether the subject believes that masks protect others after the intervention. mskblfs_prtctyou: whether the subject believes that masks protect the wearer after the intervention. pool_self: own mask wearing behavior in the vignette scenario, 1 means they would continue the activity without a mask, 2 means they would continue the activity without a mask while keeping distance from others, 3 means they would abandon the activity, 4 means they would go retrieve their mask and then continue the activity. pool_other: behavior when someone else is not wearing their mask properly, 1 means they would continue the activity as normal, 2 means they would continue the activity as normal while keeping distance from others, 3 means they would abandon the activity, 4 means they would ask the other person to wear the mask properly. pool_self_others: whether others are wearing masks in the first vignette scenario. pool_other_others: whether others are wearing masks in the second vignette scenario
natural_language_query: How much does greater mask use increase the likelihood that someone would encourage others to wear a mask?
control_variables: pool_other_scenario_atm, pool_other_scenario_meet, age, female, lucid_hhi, lucid_incmissing, ethnicity, education, workstatus, fluvaccine, partisanship_1, partisanship_2, partisanship_3, partisanship_5, partisanship_6, partisanship_7

T_mask_protectother: whether the subject was in the "Mask Protects Others" group. mskblfs_prtctothers: whether the subject believes that masks protect others after the intervention. mskblfs_prtctyou: whether the subject believes that masks protect the wearer after the intervention. pool_self: own mask wearing behavior in the vignette scenario, 1 means they would continue the activity without a mask, 2 means they would continue the activity without a mask while keeping distance from others, 3 means they would abandon the activity, 4 means they would go retrieve their mask and then continue the activity. pool_other: behavior when someone else is not wearing their mask properly, 1 means they would continue the activity as normal, 2 means they would continue the activity as normal while keeping distance from others, 3 means they would abandon the activity, 4 means they would ask the other person to wear the mask properly. pool_self_others: whether others are wearing masks in the first vignette scenario. pool_other_others: whether others are wearing masks in the second vignette scenario
natural_language_query: How much does providing information about how masks protect others increase the belief that masks protect the wearer?
control_variables: age, female, lucid_hhi, lucid_incmissing, ethnicity, education, workstatus, fluvaccine, partisanship_1, partisanship_2, partisanship_3, partisanship_5, partisanship_6, partisanship_7

paper_name: Experimental evidence that changing beliefs about mask efficacy and social norms increase mask wearing for COVID-19 risk reduction: Results from the United States and Italy
description: The randomized experiment examines the causal relationship between beliefs, social norms, and reported intentions to engage in mask promoting behavior. Subjects are randomly assigned to a control group, a "Mask Protects You" group, and a "Mask Protects Others" group. The control group reads a message unrelated to the experiment, the "Mask Protects You" group reads a message about how masks protect the wearer, and the "Mask Protects Others" group reads a message about how masks protect others. After the treatment, subjects are asked about their beliefs about masks. They then read three vignette scenarios, taking place at an ATM, in a park or in a meeting in their neighborhood. In the first scenario, they are asked about what they would do when they have forgotten to bring their mask. In the second scenario, they are asked about what they would do if someone else was not wearing their mask properly. In the third scenario, they are asked about their evaluation of someone who took action against someone not wearing their mask properly. Variables in the dataset: age: age of the subject. female: whether the subject is female. lucid_hhi: household income. lucid_incmissing: whether the subject's income is missing. ethnicity: ethnicity of the subject. education: education level of the subject. workstatus: work status of the subject. fluvaccine: whether the subject has received the flu vaccine. pool_self_scenario_atm: whether the first vignette scenario takes place at an ATM. pool_self_scenario_meet: whether the first vignette scenario takes place in a meeting in the neighborhood. pool_other_scenario_atm: whether the second vignette scenario takes place at an ATM. pool_other_scenario_meet: whether the second vignette scenario takes place in a meeting in the neighborhood. partisanship_1: whether the subject is a strong democrat. partisanship_2: whether the subject is a democrat. partisanship_3: whether the subject is a democrat lean. partisanship_4: whether the subject is an independent. partisanship_5: whether the subject is a republican lean. partisanship_6: whether the subject is a republican. partisanship_7: whether the subject is a strong republican. T_mask_protectyou: whether the subject was in the "Mask Protects You" group. T_mask_protectother: whether the subject was in the "Mask Protects Others" group. mskblfs_prtctothers: whether the subject believes that masks protect others after the intervention. mskblfs_prtctyou: whether the subject believes that masks protect the wearer after the intervention. pool_self: own mask wearing behavior in the vignette scenario, 1 means they would continue the activity without a mask, 2 means they would continue the activity without a mask while keeping distance from others, 3 means they would abandon the activity, 4 means they would go retrieve their mask and then continue the activity. pool_other: behavior when someone else is not wearing their mask properly, 1 means they would continue the activity as normal, 2 means they would continue the activity as normal while keeping distance from others, 3 means they would abandon the activity, 4 means they would ask the other person to wear the mask properly. pool_self_others: whether others are wearing masks in the first vignette scenario. pool_other_others: whether others are wearing masks in the second vignette scenario
natural_language_query: How much does providing information about how masks protect the wearer increase the belief that masks protect the wearer?
control_variables: age, female, lucid_hhi, lucid_incmissing, ethnicity, education, workstatus, fluvaccine, partisanship_1, partisanship_2, partisanship_3, partisanship_5, partisanship_6, partisanship_7

paper_name: Cities as Lobbyists
description: The dataset assembles city-level information on lobbying, federal resource allocation, connectivity to Washington, DC, and local demographic, fiscal, and political context for 1,262 U.S. cities with populations over 25,000 between 1999 and 2012. It links lobbying disclosures filed under the Lobbying Disclosure Act to Census/ACS demographics, Census of Governments fiscal data, federal earmark records, and airline route information to study how variation in public-goods provision and political environment relates to cities’ lobbying behavior and the earmarks they receive. Variables in the dataset id: Internal numeric identifier for each city in the replication dataset released with the article.​ city: Name of the city (municipal government) included in the sample of U.S. cities with population above 25,000.​​ state: U.S. state in which the city is located, used to link to state-level fiscal and political data.​​ direct_flight_dc: Indicator for whether there is at least one direct commercial flight between the city’s local (or nearby) airport and any of the Washington, DC–area airports (BWI, DCA, or IAD) in the relevant period, capturing the convenience of travel to the capital and used as an instrument for city lobbying expenditures.​​ earmark: Total dollar amount of federal congressional earmarks awarded to the city in fiscal years 2008 and 2009, typically summed across those years and expressed in constant (2012) dollars.​ city_lobbying: Total federal lobbying expenditures by the city government, based on Lobbying Disclosure Act reports, aggregated over the analysis window (e.g., around 2007–2009) and inflation-adjusted, with this variable serving as the core measure of city lobbying effort (often log-transformed in analysis).​​ state_lobbying: Total lobbying expenditures by the state government over a comparable period, providing a measure of higher-level governmental lobbying that may complement or compete with city efforts.​ county_lobbying: Total lobbying expenditures by the county government in which the city is located, used to capture additional substate lobbying that can affect how much federal funding ultimately flows to the city (and is found to be negatively related to city earmarks and grants).​ pop_e: City population, drawn from the Decennial Census and ACS and extrapolated to match the analysis years, providing a size control for lobbying and earmark outcomes.​​ land_e: Land area of the city (in square miles), as reported by Census geography files and used as a basic geographic control.​ water_e: Water area of the city (in square miles), capturing the extent of water within city boundaries, again from Census geography data.​ senior_e: Share of the city population aged 65 or older, constructed from Census/ACS age distributions and extrapolated to the analysis years.​ student_e: Share of residents enrolled in school, capturing educational-age composition and demand for education-related public goods.​ ethnic_e: Index of ethnic heterogeneity (ethnic fractionalization) at the city level, typically constructed from Census/ACS racial and ethnic composition using a fractionalization formula where higher values indicate more ethnically diverse cities, which the paper links to public-goods provision and lobbying.​ mincome_e: Median household income in the city (often in thousands of dollars), measured using Census/ACS and extrapolated to the relevant period as an indicator of overall economic status.​​ unemp_e: City unemployment rate, capturing local labor-market conditions that may influence fiscal stress and demand for federal resources.​ poverty_e: Share of households in poverty in the city, reflecting economic disadvantage and potential demand for redistributive public goods.​ gini_e: Gini coefficient of income inequality at the city level, measuring the extent of income dispersion and used in the paper as a key determinant of lobbying behavior.​​ city_taxshare_e: Share of total city revenue coming from own-source taxes (summed across tax instruments), capturing how reliant the city is on its own tax base rather than external transfers.​ city_propertytaxshare_e: Share of total city revenue specifically derived from property taxes, reflecting dependence on the property tax base and related fiscal capacity.​ city_intgovrevenueshare_e: Share of total city revenue coming from intergovernmental transfers (state and federal), measuring how much of the city’s budget is financed by higher-level governments rather than local sources.​ houdem_e: Indicator that the city’s U.S. House representative (in the district containing the city) is a Democrat, based on congressional delegation data matched via county–district crosswalks.​​ sendem_e: Indicator that at least one of the state’s U.S. Senators representing the city is a Democrat, capturing partisan alignment with the federal legislature.​​ govdem_e: Indicator that the state’s governor is a Democrat, capturing partisan control at the state executive level, which is theorized to affect state support for local public goods.​ diverge1_e: First measure of the “public goods gap” between city and state, defined as the difference between the city’s direct expenditures per capita and the corresponding state government’s direct expenditures per capita, capturing how much more (or less) the city spends than the state overall.​ diverge2_e: Second measure of the “public goods gap,” defined as the difference between the city’s direct expenditures per capita and the per capita state transfers to that city, measuring the portion of city spending not covered by state government support.​ st_airexp_e: Per-capita state government expenditure on air transportation and related functions (from the Census of Governments), used as a state-level control related to air infrastructure that may correlate with the presence of airports and airline routes.​ city_airexp_e: Per-capita city expenditure on air transportation (e.g., airports and related infrastructure), providing a city-level measure of investment in air facilities and helping to account for baseline air-service conditions when using direct flights as an instrument.
natural_language_query: How much does the money spent on lobbying increase the received amount of recovery act grants?
control_variables: state, pop_r, land_r, water_r, senior_r, student_r, ethnic_r, mincome_r, unemp_r, poverty_r, gini_r, city_propertytaxshare_r, city_intgovrevenueshare_r, city_airexp_r, houdem_r, ln_countylob

control_variables: state, pop_e, land_e, water_e, senior_e, student_e, ethnic_e, mincome_e, unemp_e, poverty_e, gini_e, city_propertytaxshare_e, city_intgovrevenueshare_e, city_airexp_e, houdem_e, ln_countylob

paper_name: All in the Family: Partisan Disagreement and Electoral Mobilization in Intimate Networks
description: This study examines political engagement and voting behavior among residents of Birmingham, UK during the West Midlands Police and Crime Commissioner election held on November 15, 2012. The dataset captures information from multiple electoral wards within the city and includes detailed demographic, contact, and electoral participation records for individuals and their household members. The dataset represents a comprehensive electoral database maintained by the local Labour Party organization, containing canvassing information collected through door-to-door and telephone contact efforts with registered voters. This information includes self-reported party preferences and validated turnout records from public electoral registers. The data covers approximately 38% of registered voters in the targeted constituencies and provides a detailed view of political engagement patterns across different demographic groups and geographic areas within Birmingham during this specific electoral period. Variable Descriptions: person_id: Unique identifier for each individual in the dataset. hh_id: Household identifier linking individuals who reside at the same address. ward: Electoral ward designation within Birmingham where the individual is registered to vote. title: Personal title or form of address (e.g., Mr., Mrs., Ms.). age: Individual's age at the time of data collection. landlinemobileboth: Type of telephone service available for the individual (landline, mobile, or both). currentabsentvoter: Registration status indicating whether the individual is registered for postal/absentee voting. latestvoterid: Most recent voter identification number on record. local2012: Participation record in local elections held in 2012. local2011: Participation record in local elections held in 2011. General2010: Participation record in the 2010 General Election. elect5: Participation record in a previous election (fifth historical record). elect6: Participation record in a previous election (sixth historical record). elect7: Participation record in a previous election (seventh historical record). elect8: Participation record in a previous election (eighth historical record). random: Randomization assignment indicator used for research design purposes. treatment: Experimental group assignment for individuals in the study. contact: Indicator of whether contact was successfully made with the individual. vote_PCC2012: Voting participation in the November 2012 Police and Crime Commissioner election.
natural_language_query: Among unassigned household members, what is the effect of assigning a low‑partisan message to the other household member on turnout?
reference: Foos & de Rooij (2016), AJPS, Table 1 (Combined), replication dataset.
